text:
[b'23 LC 33 9320
', b'S. B. 141
', b'- 1 -Senate Bill 141
', b'By: Senators Dixon of the 45th, Gooch of the 51s t, Harbin of the 16th, Robertson of the 29th,
', b'Still of the 48th and others 
', b'A BILL TO BE ENTITLED
', b'AN ACT
', b'To amend Chapter 1 of Title 43 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to1
', b'general provisions relative to professions and businesses, so as to prohibit health care2
', b"providers from performing specified practices on minors relating to altering a person's3
", b'appearance relating to gender; to prohibit health care providers from aiding or abetting such4
', b'practices for minors; to provide for definitions; to provide for exceptions; to provide for5
', b'enforcement; to amend Part 3 of Article 16 of Chapter 2 of Title 20 of the Official Code of 6
', b'Georgia Annotated, relating to student health, so as to prohibit school nurses and other7
', b"employees and officials from engaging in certain conduct relating to a minor's perception of8
", b'his or her gender; to provide for legislative fi ndings; to provide for related matters; to provide 9
', b'for an effective date; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes.10
', b'BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF GEORGIA: 11
', b'SECTION 1. 12
', b'The General Assembly finds and declares that:13
', b'(1)  This state has a compelling government interest in protecting the health and safety of 14
', b'its citizens, especially vulnerable children; 1523 LC 33 9320
', b'S. B. 141
', b'- 2 -(2)  Only a tiny percentage of the American population experiences distress at identifying 16
', b'with their biological sex.  According to the American Psychiatric Association, prevalence 17
', b'ranges from 0.005 to 0.014 percent for natal adult males and from 0.002 to 0.003 percent 18
', b'for natal females; 19
', b'(3)  Studies consistently demonstrate that the vast majority of children who are gender 20
', b'nonconforming or experience distress at identifying with their biological sex come to 21
', b'identify with their biological sex in adolescence or adulthood, thereby rendering most 22
', b'medical health care interventions unnecessary; 23
', b'(4)  Scientific studies show that individuals struggling with distress at identifying with their 24
', b'biological sex of ten have already experienced psychopathology, which indicates these 25
', b'individuals should be encouraged to seek me ntal health care services before undertaking 26
', b'any hormonal or surgical intervention; 27
', b'(5)  Suicide rates, psychiatric morbidities, and mortality rates remain markedly elevated 28
', b'above the background population after inpatient gender reassignment procedures have been 29
', b'performed; 30
', b'(6)  Some health care providers are prescribing puberty-blocking drugs in order to delay 31
', b'the onset or progression of normally timed puberty in children who experience distress at 32
', b'identifying with their biological sex.  This is being done despite the lack of any long-term 33
', b'longitudinal studies evaluating the risks and benefits of using these drugs for the treatment 34
', b'of such distress or gender transition; 35
', b'(7)  Health care providers are also prescribing cross-sex hormones for children who 36
', b'experience distress at identifying with their biological sex, despite the fact that no 37
', b'randomized clinical trials have been conducted on the efficacy or safety of the use of 38
', b'cross-sex hormones in adults or children for the purpose of treating such distress or gender 39
', b'transition; 40
', b'(8)  The use of cross-sex hormones comes with the following serious known risks: 4123 LC 33 9320
', b'S. B. 141
', b'- 3 -(A)  For biological females, erythrocytosis, severe liver dysfunction, coronary artery 42
', b'disease, cerebrovascular disease, hypertension, increased risk of breast and uterine 43
', b'cancers, and irreversible infertility; and 44
', b'(B)  For biological males, thromboembolic disease, cholelithiasis, coronary artery 45
', b'disease, macroprolactinoma, cerebrovascular disease, hypertriglyceridemia, breast cancer, 46
', b'and irreversible infertility; 47
', b'(9)  Genital and non-genital reassignment surgeries are generally not recommended for 48
', b'children, although evidence indicates referrals for children to have such surgeries are 49
', b'becoming more frequent; 50
', b'(10)  Genital gender reassignment surgery incl udes several irreversible  invasive procedures 51
', b'for males and females and involves the following alterations of biologically normal and 52
', b'functional body parts: 53
', b'(A)  For biological males, surgery may involve genital reconstruction including 54
', b'penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, and vulvoplasty; and 55
', b'(B)  For biological females, surgery may involve a hysterectomy or oophorectomy, 56
', b'reconstruction of the urethra, genital reconstruction including metoidioplasty or 57
', b'phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, and implantation of erection or testicular 58
', b'prostheses; 59
', b'(11)  The complications, risks, and long-term care concerns associated with genital gender 60
', b'reassignment surgery for both males and females are numerous and complex; 61
', b'(12)  Non-genital gender reassignment surgery includes various invasive procedures for 62
', b'males and females and also involves the alte ration or removal of biologically normal and 63
', b'functional body parts: 64
', b'(A)  For biological males, procedures may include augmentation mammoplasty, facial 65
', b'feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, 66
', b'gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, and other aesthetic procedures; and 6723 LC 33 9320
', b'S. B. 141
', b'- 4 -(B)  For biological females, procedures may include subcutaneous mastectomy, voice 68
', b'surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, and other aesthetic procedures; 69
', b'(13)  It is an accepted principle of economics and public policy that when a service or 70
', b'product is subsidized or paid for, demand for that service or product increases.  Just 71
', b'between 2015 and 2016, gender reassignment surgeries increased by 20 percent; 72
', b'(14)  It is of grave concern that the medical community is allowing individuals who 73
', b'experience distress at identifying with their biological sex to be subjects of irreversible and 74
', b'drastic non-genital gender reassignment surgery and irreversible, permanently sterilizing 75
', b'genital gender reassignment surgery, despite the lack of studies showing that the benefits 76
', b'of such extreme interventions outweigh the risks; and 77
', b'(15)  The risks of gender transition procedures far outweigh any benefit at this stage of 78
', b'clinical study on these procedures. 79
', b'SECTION 2. 80
', b'Chapter 1 of Title 43 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to general81
', b'provisions relative to professions and businesse s, is amending by adding a new Code section 82
', b'to read as follows:83
', b'"43-1-36. 84
', b'(a)  As used in this Code section, the term: 85
', b"(1) 'Health care provider' means any person licensed under Chapter 9, 10A, 11, 11A, 26, 86
", b'28, 30, 33, 34, 35, 39, or 44 of Title 43 or any hospital, nursing home, home health 87
', b'agency, institution, or medical facility licensed or defined under Chapter 7 of Title 31. 88
', b'Such term shall also include any corporation, professional corporation, partnership, 89
', b'limited liability company, limited liability partnership, authority, or other entity 90
', b'composed of such health care providers. 91
', b"(2)  'Sex' means the biological indication of male and female, including sex 92
", b'chromosomes, naturally occurring sex horm ones, gonads, and nonambiguous internal and 9323 LC 33 9320
', b'S. B. 141
', b"- 5 -external genitalia present at birth, without re gard to an individual' s psychological, chosen, 94
", b'or subjective experience of gender. 95
', b'(b)  Except as otherwise provided in subsecti on (d) of this Code section, no health care 96
', b'provider in this state shall knowingly engage in or cause any of the following practices to 97
', b'be performed upon any minor if the practice is performed for the purpose of attempting to 98
', b"alter the appearance of or affirm the minor's perception of his or her gender or sex, if that 99
", b"appearance or perception is inconsistent with the minor's sex: 100
", b'(1)  Prescribing or administering gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues or other 101
', b'synthetic drugs used to stop luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone 102
', b'secretion, synthetic antiandrogen drugs used to block the androgen receptor, or any drug 103
', b'to suppress or delay normal puberty; 104
', b'(2)  Prescribing or administering testosterone, estrogen, or progesterone to a minor in an 105
', b'amount greater than would normally be produced endogenously in a healthy individual 106
', b"of that individual's age and sex; 107
", b'(3)  Performing surgeries that sterilize, including castration, vasectomy, hysterectomy, 108
', b'oophorectomy, orchiectomy, and penectomy; 109
', b'(4)  Performing surgeries that artificially construct tissue with the appearance of genitalia 110
', b"that differs from the individual's sex, including metoidioplasty, phalloplasty, and 111
", b'vaginoplasty; or 112
', b'(5)  Removing any healthy or nondiseased body part or tissue. 113
', b'(c)  No health care provider shall knowingly engage in conduct that aids or abets the 114
', b'practices described in subsection (b) of this Code section on any minor. 115
', b'(d)  Subsections (b) and (c) of this Code section shall not apply to: 116
', b'(1)  Services provided to individuals born with a medically verifiable disorder of sex 117
', b'development, including a person with external biological sex characteristics that are 118
', b'irresolvably ambiguous, such as an individual born with 46 XX chromosomes with 11923 LC 33 9320
', b'S. B. 141
', b'- 6 -virilization, 46 XY chromosomes with undervirilization, or having both ovarian and 120
', b'testicular tissue; 121
', b'(2)  Services provided to an individual when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a 122
', b'disorder of sexual development, in which the physician has determined through genetic 123
', b'or biochemical testing that the individual does not have normal sex chromosome 124
', b'structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid hormone action for a biological 125
', b'male or biological female; 126
', b'(3)  The treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has been caused or 127
', b'exacerbated by the performance of a procedure described in subsection (b) of this Code 128
', b'section, whether or not the procedures were performed in accordance with state and 129
', b'federal law; or 130
', b'(4)  Any procedure undertaken because an individual suffers from a physical disorder, 131
', b'physical injury, or physical illness that is certified by a physician and that would place 132
', b'the individual in imminent danger of death or impairment of major bodily function unless 133
', b'surgery is performed. 134
', b'(e)(1)  The provision of services to or engaging in conduct regarding any minor described 135
', b'in subsections (b) and (c) of this Code section shall be considered unprofessional conduct 136
', b'and shall be subject to discipline by the licensing entity with jurisdiction over the health 137
', b'care provider. 138
', b'(2)  A person may assert an actual or threatened  violation of this Code section as a claim 139
', b'or defense in a judicial or administrative proceeding and obtain compensatory damages, 140
', b'injunctive relief, declaratory relief, or any other appropriate relief. 141
', b'(3)  A person shall be required to bring a cl aim for a violation of this Code section not 142
', b'later than two years after the  day the cause of action accrues.  A minor may bring an 143
', b'action before reaching 18 years of age thr ough a parent or guar dian, and may bring an 144
', b"action in the minor's own name upon reaching 18 years of age at any time from that point 145
", b'until he or she reaches 38 years of age. 14623 LC 33 9320
', b'S. B. 141
', b'- 7 -(4)  An action under this Code section may be commenced, and relief may be granted, in 147
', b'a judicial proceeding without regard to whether the person commencing the action has 148
', b'sought or exhausted available administrative remedies. 149
', b'(5)  In any action or proceeding to enforce a provision of this Code section, a prevailing 150
', b'party who establishes a violation of this Code section shall be entitled to recover 151
', b"reasonable attorney's fees. 152
", b'(6)  The Attorney General may bring an action to enforce compliance with this Code 153
', b'section.  Nothing in this Code section shall be construed to deny, impair, or otherwise 154
', b'affect any right or authority of the Attorney General, the state, or any agency, officer, or 155
', b'employee of the state to institute or intervene in any proceeding. 156
', b'(f)  Nothing in this Code section shall be construed to impose liability on any speech or 157
', b'conduct protected by federal or state law. " 158
', b'SECTION 3. 159
', b'Part 3 of Article 16 of Chapter 2 of Title 20 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, 160
', b'relating to student health, is amended by adding a new Code section to read as follows: 161
', b'"20-2-779.3. 162
', b"(a)  As used in this Code section, the term 'sex' means the biological indication of male and 163
", b'female, including sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, and 164
', b'nonambiguous internal and external genitalia present at birth, without regard to an 165
', b"individual's psychological, chosen, or subjective experience of gender. 166
", b'(b)  No school nurse, counselor, teacher, principal, or other official or staff at a public or 167
', b'private school shall knowingly: 168
', b"(1)  Encourage or coerce a minor to withhold from the minor's parent or legal guardian 169
", b"the fact that the minor's perception of his or her gender is inconsistent with his or her sex; 170
", b'or 17123 LC 33 9320
', b'S. B. 141
', b"- 8 -(2)  Withhold from a minor's parent or legal guardian information related to the minor's 172
", b'perception that his or her gender is inconsistent with his or her sex. " 173
', b'SECTION 4. 174
', b'This Act shall become effective on January 1, 2024. 175
', b'SECTION 5. 176
', b'All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are repealed. 177']

', b'24  STATE OF OKLAHOMA

', b'1st Session of the 59th Legislature (2023)

', b'SENATE BILL  129 By: Bullard 
', b'

', b'AS INTRODUCED  
', b' 
', b'An Act relating to health care; creating the  
', b'Millstone Act of 2023 ; defining terms; p rohibiting 
', b'provision of or referral for gender tran sition 
', b'procedures ; providing exceptions; pro hibiting certain 
', b'uses of public funds, public facilities , public 
', b'employees , and state Medicaid program ; providing for 
', b'criminal, administrative , and civil enforce ment; 
', b'authorizing certain civil actions  and relief ; 
', b'providing certain construction; providing for 
', b'codification; and declari ng an emergency . 
', b' 
', b' 
', b' 
', b' 
', b'BE IT ENACTED BY THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF OKLAHOMA:  
', b'SECTION 1.     NEW LAW     A new s ection of law to be codified 
', b'in the Oklahoma Statut es as Section 2607.1 of Title 63, unless there 
', b'is created a duplication in numbering, reads as follows:  
', b'This act shall be known and may be cited as the Millstone Act o f 
', b'2023. 
', b'SECTION 2.     NEW LAW     A new section of law to be codified 
', b'in the Oklahoma Statutes as Section 2607.2 of Title 63, unless there 
', b'is created a duplication in numbering, reads as follows:  
', b'As used in this act:   
', b' 
', b' 
', b'Req. No. 3  Page 2 
', b' 1 
', b'2

', b'24  1.  \xe2\x80\x9cBiological sex \xe2\x80\x9d means the bi ological indication of male  and 
', b'female in the context of reproductive potentia l or capacity, such as 
', b'sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, and 
', b'nonambiguous internal and external genita lia present at birth, 
', b'without regard to an individu al\xe2\x80\x99s psychological, chosen,  or 
', b'subjective experience of gender;  
', b'2.  \xe2\x80\x9cCross-sex hormones \xe2\x80\x9d means: 
', b'a. testosterone or other androgens given to biological 
', b'females in amounts that are larger or more potent than  
', b'would normally occur naturally in healt hy biologic al 
', b'sex females , and 
', b'b. estrogen given to biological males in amounts that are  
', b'larger or more potent than would normally occur 
', b'naturally in healthy biological sex males;  
', b'3.  \xe2\x80\x9cGender\xe2\x80\x9d means the psychological , behavioral, social, and 
', b'cultural aspe cts of being  male or female;  
', b'4.  \xe2\x80\x9cGender reassignment surgery \xe2\x80\x9d means any medical or surgic al 
', b'service that seeks to surgically alter or remove healthy physical or 
', b'anatomical characteristics or features that are typical  for the 
', b'individual \xe2\x80\x99s biological sex, i n order to i nstill or create 
', b'physiologi cal or anatomical characteristics that resemble a s ex 
', b'different from the individual \xe2\x80\x99s biological sex, including but not 
', b'limited to genital or nongenital gender reassignment surge ry  
', b'

', b'24  performed for the purpose of assisti ng an indivi dual with a gender 
', b'transiti on; 
', b'5.  \xe2\x80\x9cGender transition \xe2\x80\x9d means the process in wh ich a person goes 
', b'from identifying with and living as a gender that corresponds to his 
', b'or her biological sex to identifying wit h and living as a gender

Roy, Rock. 31; Rep. Spillane, Rock. 2; Rep. McCarter, Belk. 8; Rep. Verville, Rock. 2; Rep. Notter, Hills. 12; Rep. Seidel, Hills. 29; Rep. A. Lekas, Hills. 38; Rep. Love, Rock. 13\xc2\xa0COMMITTEE:\tHealth, Human Services and Elderly Affairs\xc2\xa0-----------------------------------------------------------------\xc2\xa0ANALYSIS\xc2\xa0\tThis bill prohibits gender transition care for minors under 18 years of age, prohibits teaching about gender identity in public schools and changes the definition of conversion therapy.\xc2\xa0- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - \xc2\xa0Explanation:\tMatter added to current law appears in bold italics.\t\tMatter removed from current law appears [in brackets and struckthrough.]\t\tMatter which is either (a) all new or (b) repealed and reenacted appears in regular type.\t23-0071\t02/05\xc2\xa0STATE OF NEW HAMPSHIRE\xc2\xa0In the Year of Our Lord Two Thousand Twenty Three\xc2\xa0AN ACT\tprohibiting gender transition procedures for minors, relative to sex and gender in public schools, and relative to the definition of conversion therapy. \xc2\xa0Be it Enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives in General Court convened:\xc2\xa0 1 \xc2\xa0Title. \xc2\xa0This act shall be known and may be cited as the "Protection Against Child Medical and Psychological Experimentation Act". 2 \xc2\xa0Legislative Findings. \xc2\xa0The general court finds that:\t\tI.  New Hampshire has a compelling government interest in protecting the health and safety of its citizens, especially vulnerable children;\t\tII.(a)  Only a small percentage of the American population experiences distress at identifying with their biological sex. \t\t\t(b)  According to the American Psychiatric Association, \xe2\x80\x9cFor natal adult males, prevalence ranges from 0.005 to 0.014 percent, and for natal females, from 0.002 to 0.003 percent.\xe2\x80\x9d;\t\tIII.  For the small percentage of children who are gender nonconforming or experience distress at identifying with their biological sex, studies consistently demonstrate that the majority come to identify with their biological sex in adolescence or adulthood, thereby rendering most physiological interventions unnecessary;\t\tIV.  Furthermore, scientific studies show that individuals struggling with distress at identifying with their biological sex often have already experienced psychopathology, which indicates these individuals should be encouraged to seek mental health services to address comorbidities and underlying causes of their distress before undertaking any hormonal or surgical intervention;\t\tV.  Even among people who have undergone inpatient gender reassignment procedures, suicide rates, psychiatric morbidities, and mortality rates remain markedly elevated above the background population;\t\tVI.(a)  Some health care providers are prescribing puberty blocking drugs, such as gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues, in order to delay the onset or progression of puberty in children who experience distress at identifying with their biological sex.\t\t\t(b)  The prescribing of puberty-blocking drugs is being done despite the lack of any long-term longitudinal studies evaluating the risks and benefits of using these drugs for the treatment of such distress or gender transition;\t\tVII.  Health care providers are also prescribing cross-sex hormones for children who experience distress at identifying with their biological sex, despite the fact that no randomized clinical trials have been conducted on the efficacy or safety of the use of cross-sex hormones in adults or children for the purpose of treating such distress or gender transition;\t\tVIII.  The use of cross-sex hormones comes with serious known risks, such as:\t\t\t(a)  For biological females:\t\t\t\t(1)  Erythrocytosis, which is an increase in red blood cells;\t\t\t\t(2)  Severe liver dysfunction;\t\t\t\t(3)  Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks;\t\t\t\t(4)  Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes;\t\t\t\t(5)  Hypertension;\t\t\t\t(6)  Increased risk of breast and uterine cancers; and \t\t\t\t(7)  Irreversible infertility; and\t\t\t(b)  For biological males:\t\t\t\t(1)  Thromboembolic disease, including blood clots;\t\t\t\t(2)  Cholelithiasis, including gallstones;\t\t\t\t(3)  Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks;\t\t\t\t(4)  Macroprolactinoma, which is a tumor of the pituitary gland;\t\t\t\t(5)  Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes;\t\t\t\t(6)  Hypertriglyceridemia, which is an elevated level of triglycerides in the blood;\t\t\t\t(7)  Breast cancer; and \t\t\t\t(8)  Irreversible infertility;\t\tIX.  Genital and non-genital gender reassignment surgeries are generally not recommended for children, although evidence indicates referrals for children to have such surgeries are becoming more frequent;\t\tX.(a)  Genital gender reassignment surgery includes several irreversible invasive procedures for males and females and involves the alteration of biologically healthy and functional body parts.\t\t\t(b)  For biological males, surgery may involve:\t\t\t\t(1)  Genital reconstruction including penectomy, which is the removal of the penis;\t\t\t\t(2)  Orchiectomy, which is the removal of the testicles;\t\t\t\t(3)  Vaginoplasty, which is the construction of a vagina-like structure, typically through a penile inversion procedure;\t\t\t\t(4)  Clitoroplasty, which is the construction of a clitoris-like structure; and \t\t\t\t(5)  Vulvoplasty, which is the construction of a vulva-like structure.\t\t\t(c)  For biological females, surgery may involve:\t\t\t\t(1)  A hysterectomy or oophorectomy;\t\t\t\t(2)  Reconstruction of the urethra;\t\t\t\t(3)  Genital reconstruction including metoidioplasty or phalloplasty, which is the construction of a penis-like structure;\t\t\t\t(4)  Vaginectomy, which is the removal of the vagina;\t\t\t\t(5)  Scrotoplasty, which is the construction of a penis-like and scrotum-like structure; and \t\t\t\t(6)  Implantation of erection or testicular prostheses;\t\tXI.  The complications, risks, and long-term care concerns associated with genital gender reassignment surgery for both males and females are numerous and complex;\t\tXII.(a)  Non-genital gender reassignment surgery includes various invasive procedures for males and females and also involves the alteration or removal of biologically normal and functional body parts.\t\t\t(b)  For biological males, this surgery may involve:\t\t\t\t(1)  Augmentation mammoplasty; \t\t\t\t(2)  Facial feminization surgery;\t\t\t\t(3)  Liposuction;\t\t\t\t(4)  Lipofilling;\t\t\t\t(5)  Voice surgery;\t\t\t\t(6)  Thyroid cartilage reduction;\t\t\t\t(7)  Gluteal augmentation;\t\t\t\t(8)  Hair reconstruction; and \t\t\t\t(9)  Other aesthetic procedures. \t\t\t(c)  For biological females, this surgery may involve:\t\t\t\t(1)  A subcutaneous mastectomy;\t\t\t\t(2)  Voice surgery;\t\t\t\t(3)  Liposuction;\t\t\t\t(4)  Lipofilling;\t\t\t\t(5)  Pectoral implants; and \t\t\t\t(6)  Other aesthetic procedures;\t\tXIII.(a)  It is an accepted principle of economics and public policy that when a service or product is subsidized or reimbursed, demand for that service or product is increased.\t\t\t(b)  Between 2015 and 2016, gender reassignment surgeries increased by nearly twenty percent in the United States;\t\tXIV.  It is of grave concern to the general court that the medical community is allowing individuals who experience distress at identifying with their biological sex to be subjects of irreversible and drastic non-genital gender reassignment surgery and irreversible, permanently sterilizing genital gender reassignment surgery, despite the lack of studies showing that the benefits of such extreme interventions outweigh the risks; and\t\tXV.  The risks of gender transition procedures far outweigh any benefit at this stage of clinical study on these procedures.  3 \xc2\xa0New Chapter; System of Gender Dysphoria Care for Minors. \xc2\xa0Amend RSA by inserting after chapter 135-F the following new chapter:CHAPTER 135-GSYSTEM OF GENDER DYSPHORIA CARE FOR MINORS\t135-G:1 \xc2\xa0Definitions. \xc2\xa0In this chapter:\t\tI.  "Biological sex\xe2\x80\x9d means the biological indication of male and female in the context of reproductive potential or capacity, such as sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, and non-ambiguous internal and external genitalia present at birth, without regard to an individual\xe2\x80\x99s psychological, chosen, or subjective experience of gender.\t\tII.  \xe2\x80\x9cCross-sex hormones\xe2\x80\x9d means:\t\t\t(a)  Testosterone or other androgens given to biological females in amounts that are larger or more potent than would normally occur naturally in healthy biological sex females; and\t\t\t(b)  Estrogen given to biological males in amounts that are larger or more potent than would normally occur naturally in healthy biological sex males.\t\tIII.  \xe2\x80\x9cGender\xe2\x80\x9d means the psychological, behavioral, social, and cultural aspects of being male or female.\t\tIV.  \xe2\x80\x9cGender reassignment surgery\xe2\x80\x9d means any medical or surgical service that seeks to surgically alter or remove healthy physical or anatomical characteristics or features that are typical for the individual\xe2\x80\x99s biological sex, in order to instill or create physiological or anatomical characteristics that resemble a sex different from the individual\xe2\x80\x99s biological sex, including without limitation, genital or nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition.\t\tV.  \xe2\x80\x9cGender transition\xe2\x80\x9d means the process in which a person goes from identifying with and living as a gender that corresponds to his or her biological sex to identifying with and living as a gender different from his or her biological sex, and may involve social, legal, or physical changes.\t\tVI.(a)  \xe2\x80\x9cGender transition procedures\xe2\x80\x9d means any medical or surgical service, including without limitation physician\'s services, inpatient and outpatient hospital services, or prescribed drugs related to gender transition that seeks to:\t\t\t\t(1)  Alter or remove physical or anatomical characteristics or features that are typical for the individual\xe2\x80\x99s biological sex; or\t\t\t\t(2)  Instill or create physiological or anatomical characteristics that resemble a sex different from the individual\xe2\x80\x99s biological sex, including without limitation medical services that provide puberty blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, or other mechanisms to promote the development of feminizing or masculinizing features in the opposite biological sex, or genital or non-genital gender reassignment surgery performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition.\t\t\t(b)  \xe2\x80\x9cGender transition procedures\xe2\x80\x9d do not include:\t\t\t\t(1)  Services to persons born with a medically verifiable disorder of sex development, including a person with external biological sex characteristics that are ambiguous, such as those born with 46 XX chromosomes with virilization, 46 XY chromosomes with undervirilization, or having both ovarian and testicular tissue;\t\t\t\t(2)  Services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a disorder of sexual development that the physician has determined through genetic or biochemical testing that the person does not have normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid hormone action;\t\t\t\t(3)  The treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has been caused by or exacerbated by the performance of gender transition procedures, whether or not the gender transition procedure was performed in accordance with state and federal law or whether not funding for the gender transition procedure is permissible under this chapter; or\t\t\t\t(4)  Any procedure undertaken because the individual suffers from a physical disorder, physical injury, or physical illness that would, as certified by a physician, place the individual in imminent danger of death or impairment of major bodily function unless surgery is performed.\t\tVII.  \xe2\x80\x9cGenital gender reassignment surgery\xe2\x80\x9d means a medical procedure performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition, including without limitation:\t\t\t(a)  Surgical procedures such as penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, or vulvoplasty for biologically male patients or hysterectomy or ovariectomy for biologically female patients; \t\t\t(b)  Reconstruction of the fixed part of the urethra with or without a metoidioplasty; or\t\t\t(c)  Phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, or implantation of erection or testicular prostheses for biologically female patients.\t\tVIII.  \xe2\x80\x9cHealth care professional\xe2\x80\x9d a person who is licensed, certified, or otherwise authorized by the laws of this state to administer health care in the ordinary course of the practice of his or her profession.\t\tIX.  \xe2\x80\x9cNon-genital gender reassignment surgery\xe2\x80\x9d means medical procedures performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition including without limitation:\t\t\t(a)  Surgical procedures for biologically male patients, such as augmentation mammoplasty, facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, or various aesthetic procedures; or \t\t\t(b)  Surgical procedures for biologically female patients, such as subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, or various aesthetic procedures.\t\tX.  \xe2\x80\x9cPhysician\xe2\x80\x9d means a person who is licensed to practice medicine in this state.\t\tXI.  \xe2\x80\x9cPuberty-blocking drugs\xe2\x80\x9d means gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues or other synthetic drugs used in biological males to stop luteinizing hormone secretion and therefore testosterone secretion, or synthetic drugs used in biological females which stop the production of estrogens and progesterone, when used to delay or suppress pubertal development in children for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition.\t\tXII.  Public funds\xe2\x80\x9d means state, county, or local government monies, in addition to any department, agency, or instrumentality authorized or appropriated under state law or derived from any fund in which such moneys are deposited.\t135-G:2 \xc2\xa0Prohibition of Gender Transition Care for Children and Young Adults. \t\tI. \xc2\xa0A physician or other health care professional shall not provide gender transition procedures to any individual under 18 years of age.\t\tII. \xc2\xa0A physician or other health care professional shall not refer any individual under 18 years of age to any health care professional for gender transition procedures.\t\tIII. \xc2\xa0A physician or other health care professional is not prohibited from providing any of the following procedures which are not gender transition procedures to an individual under 18 years of age:\t\t\t(a) \xc2\xa0Services to persons born with a medically verifiable disorder of sex development, including a person with external biological sex characteristics that are ambiguous, such as those born with 46 XX chromosomes with virilization, 46 XY chromosomes with undervirilization, or having both ovarian and testicular tissue;\t\t\t(b) \xc2\xa0Services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a disorder of sexual development that the physician has determined through genetic or biochemical testing that the person does not have normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid hormone action;\t\t\t(c) \xc2\xa0The treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has been caused by or exacerbated by the performance of gender transition procedures, whether or not the gender transition procedure was performed in accordance with state and federal law or whether not funding for the gender transition procedure is permissible under this chapter; or \t\t\t(d)  Any procedure undertaken because the individual suffers from a physical disorder, physical injury, or physical illness that would, as certified by a physician, place the individual in imminent danger of death or impairment of major bodily function unless surgery is performed.\t135-G:3 \xc2\xa0Prohibition on Use of Public Funds for Gender Transition Care. \t\tI.  Public funds shall not be directly or indirectly used, granted, paid, or distributed to any entity, organization, or individual that provides gender transition procedures to an individual under 18 years of age.\t\tII.  Health care services furnished in the following situations shall not include gender transition procedures to an individual under 18 years of age:\t\t\t(a)  By or in a health care facility owned by the state or a county or local government; or\t\t\t(b)  By a physician or other health care professional employed by state or a county or local government.\t\tIII.  The New Hampshire Medicaid program shall not reimburse or provide coverage for gender transition procedures to an individual under 18 years of age.\t135-G:4 \xc2\xa0Enforcement.\t\tI.  Any referral for or provision of gender transition procedures to an individual under 18 years of age is unprofessional conduct and is subject to discipline by the appropriate licensing entity or disciplinary review board with competent jurisdiction in this state.\t\tII. \xc2\xa0A person may assert an actual or threatened violation of this chapter as a claim or defense in a judicial or administrative proceeding and obtain compensatory damages, injunctive relief, declaratory relief, or any other appropriate relief.\t\tIII.(a)  A person shall bring a claim for a violation of this chapter no later than 2 years after the day the cause of action accrues.\t\t\t(b)  An individual under 18 years of age may bring an action during their minority through a parent or next friend, and may bring an action in their own name upon reaching majority at any time from that point until 20 years after reaching the age of majority.\t\tIV.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an action under this chapter may be commenced, and relief may be granted, in a judicial proceeding without regard to whether the person commencing the action has sought or exhausted available administrative remedies.\t\tV.  In any action or proceeding to enforce a provision of this chapter, a prevailing party who establishes a violation of this chapter shall recover reasonable attorneys\xe2\x80\x99 fees.\t\tVI.(a)  The attorney general shall bring action to enforce compliance with this chapter. \t\t\t(b)  This chapter does not deny, impair, or otherwise affect any right or authority of the attorney general, the State of New Hampshire, or any agency, officer, or employee of the state, acting under any law other than this chapter, to institute or intervene in any proceeding.\t135-G:5 \xc2\xa0Insurance Coverage.\t\tI.  No insurer that issues or renews a policy for health insurance under RSA 415, health service corporation under RSA 420-A, or health maintenance organization under RSA 420-B shall include reimbursement for gender transition procedures for a person under 18 years of age.\t\tII. \xc2\xa0No insurer that issues or renews a policy for health insurance under RSA 415, health service corporation under RSA 420-A, or health maintenance organization under RSA 420-B shall be required to provide coverage for gender transition procedures. 4 \xc2\xa0Legislative Findings Relative to Sex and Gender in Public Schools. \xc2\xa0The general court finds that:\t\tI.  Parents are the primary educators of their children.\t\tII.  Parents are solely responsible for teaching their children about matters of faith, morals, and matters relating to their sexuality.\t\tIII.  When parents choose to send their children to a public school, they do not waive their right to be the sole educator of their children about matters of faith, morals, and matters relating to their sexuality.\t\tIV.  Parents are entitled to deference in these matters and should not be contradicted by the government.\t\tV.  Modesty falls within the scope of faith, moral and sexuality teachings, and parents should expect their children to be safe to express their modesty while in a public school.\t\tVI.  Forcing a student to share a restroom, locker/changing room or shower with a student of the opposite sex is a direct contradiction to the concept of modesty and is a clear government interference in a parent\xe2\x80\x99s right to teach their children as their faith, or personal moral code allows.\t\tVII.  Teaching a student that there are more than two genders infringes on a parent\xe2\x80\x99s right to be the sole educator in matters of faith, morals and sexuality, as many religious faiths teach that there are but two genders; male and female.\t\tVIII.  Teaching a student that they are free to choose their own gender, name, pronoun, or sexual orientation violates a parent\xe2\x80\x99s right as sole educator related to matters of faith, morals and matters relating to sexuality and is a government violation of that right.\t\tIX.  There is no credible scientific evidence that a person is anything other than the gender and biological sex that they are born with and any claim to the contrary is based upon subjective, psychological, individual feelings.  This area of human study is controversial and far from settled science.  As such, teachings related to this complex and controversial concept are inappropriate for a pre-k through 12 public school setting.\t\tX.  Biological males are physically different than biological females.  Males generally, are physically stronger and as such, any physical competition between biological males and biological females is fundamentally unfair.  Furthermore, such competition can result in physical injury to the female participant if contact is involved.  Allowing biological males to participate in female sports is both dangerous and unfair to female athletes.  This diminishes female achievement, sets back women\xe2\x80\x99s rights and limits future collegiate scholarship opportunity and denies them the recognition they are due for their hard work in their sport of choice that is reserved to female athletes. 5 \xc2\xa0New Subdivision; Pupils; Sex and Gender in Public Schools. \xc2\xa0Amend RSA 193 by inserting after section 40 the following new subdivision:Sex and Gender in Public Schools\t193:41 \xc2\xa0Sex and Gender in Public Schools. \t\tI. \xc2\xa0All public schools in kindergarten through grade 12 in New Hampshire shall refer to children by the name and gender that they are enrolled as.  This shall apply to all verbal and written communications, records, or in any other way that the students may be referenced.  Schools shall not allow the teaching of different pronouns other than those in common use in the English language when referring to the male or female.  School staff shall use the appropriate pronoun for student\xe2\x80\x99s gender as listed in the enrollment by their parents.  Educators in grades kindergarten through 8, are prohibited from teaching that gender is a choice, optional or fluid and that there are more than 2 genders:  male and female.  Educators in grades 9 through 12 are prohibited from teaching that gender is a choice, optional or fluid and that there are more than 2 genders: male and female, except as a part of an approved psychology course setting where the educator is a licensed child psychologist, and they may only teach that there may be more than 2 genders in the context of teaching about the mental health condition known as gender dysphoria.  Prior to any lesson, class or assignment that proposes there are more than the male and female genders, the school shall obtain written permission from the parents.  The permission notice shall explain in detail the contents of the lesson, class or assignment.  Parents shall have the right to opt their child out of such lesson, class or assignment, and students themselves may choose not to participate if the subject matter makes them uncomfortable. \xc2\xa0Any student\xe2\x80\x99s failure to participate shall not be used in calculating their grades.  No grade or incomplete status shall be noted in the student\xe2\x80\x99s records for failure to participate in such lesson, class or assignment. \t\tII.  In any New Hampshire public school that offers regular or extracurricular activities that are separated by gender or sex (male or female), any student participating shall only be allowed to participate in the group that corresponds to their biological sex as listed at their time of birth.  No student shall be discriminated against by not being allowed to participate in such an activity based on their personally identifying as a gender other than that identified at their time of birth but they shall nonetheless only participate in the activity that corresponds to their biological sex at their time of birth.\t\tIII.  School restrooms shall be separated by sex (male and female), and students may only use the restroom that corresponds to their biological sex as listed on their birth certificate. \t\tIV.(a)  Anyone violating a provision of this subdivision shall be considered to have violated the terms of their licensure and shall be subject to discipline by their licensing authority up to and including the revocation of their license.  This shall also be considered grounds for immediate termination from employment for cause, any union or employment contract notwithstanding.\t\t\t(b)  Any student or parent aggrieved by a violation of this section may bring a cause of action in court and may be granted actual damages as well as legal fees.\t\t\t(c)  The attorney general, upon referral by the department of education, a parent or student, shall bring any necessary action to enjoin any ongoing violation of this section and defend any actions brought under this section. 6 \xc2\xa0Definition; Conversion Therapy. \xc2\xa0Amend RSA 332-L:1 to read as follows:\t332-L:1  Definition.  In this chapter, "conversion therapy" means practices or treatments that seek to change an individual\'s sexual orientation or gender identity against their clearly expressed will, including further efforts against their will to change behaviors or gender expressions or to eliminate or reduce sexual or romantic attractions or feelings toward individuals of the same gender.  Conversion therapy shall not include counseling of a child enrolled in therapy at the request of their parent for the evaluation of, and treatment for, gender dysphoria, or that provides assistance to a person undergoing therapy for gender dysphoria and who, after reaching the age of 18, wishes to discuss gender transition from or to their biological gender, or counseling that provides a person over the age of 18 acceptance, support, and understanding of a person or facilitates a person\'s coping, social support, and identity exploration and development, including sexual-orientation-neutral interventions to prevent or address unlawful conduct or unsafe sexual practices, as long as such counseling does not seek to change an individual\'s sexual orientation or gender identity against their clearly expressed will. \t7 \xc2\xa0Effective Date. \xc2\xa0This act shall take effect January 1, 2024.\xc2\xa0\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tLBA\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t23-0071\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t1/10/23\xc2\xa0HB 619-FN- FISCAL NOTEAS INTRODUCED\xc2\xa0AN ACT\tprohibiting gender transition procedures for minors, relative to sex and gender in public schools, and relative to the definition of conversion therapy. \xc2\xa0FISCAL IMPACT: \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0[ X ] State \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0[ \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0] County \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0[ \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0] Local \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0[ \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0] None\n', b'\n', b'\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\n', b'\n', b'\xc2\xa0\n', b'\n', b'\xc2\xa0Estimated Increase / (Decrease)\n', b'\n', b'STATE:FY 2023FY 2024FY 2025FY 2026\n', b'\n', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0Appropriation$0$0$0$0\n', b'\n', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0Revenue$0$0$0$0\n', b'\n', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0Expenditures$0IndeterminableIndeterminableIndeterminable\n', b'\n', b'Funding Source:\xc2\xa0 [ X ] General \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0[ \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0] Education \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0[ \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0] Highway \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0[ \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0] Other \n', b'\n', b'\xc2\xa0The Legislative Budget Assistant Office is awaiting information from the Department of Justice. \xc2\xa0The Department was contacted for a fiscal note worksheet on January 6, 2023.\xc2\xa0METHODOLOGY:This bill prohibits gender transition procedures for individuals under the age of 18 and prohibits the use of funds for these procedures. The Department of Health and Human Services anticipates a reduction in Medicaid funds as a result of the services, therapies, and medications that would no longer be performed or offered. \xc2\xa0However, the Department also anticipates that the bill may result in an "undefined level of risk" of disallowance of federal matching funds under Medicaid, as federal law and regulations are currently unsettled on the matter of whether states may prohibit public funds from being used for gender transitions and related treatments. \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0The Judicial Branch notes that violations of the proposed new chapter would be subject to civil proceedings in court. In addition, the bill creates a new subdivision in RSA 193 relative to sex and gender in public schools, and would entitle the attorney general to seek an action in court to enjoin any ongoing violation of the section. \xc2\xa0The Branch is unable to determine the number of new cases that may be brought as a result of the bill.\xc2\xa0The Department of Education states there is no anticipated costs to local school districts as a result of the bill.\xc2\xa0AGENCIES CONTACTED:Judicial Branch, and Departments of Health and Human Services, Education, and Justice\xc2\xa0']

title: Millstone Act of 2023
description: Amend The South Carolina Code Of Laws By Enacting The "millstone Act Of 2023"; And By Adding Chapter 141 To Title 44 So As To Prohibit Health Care Professionals From Making Referrals For Or Providing Gender-transition Procedures Or Services To Anyone Under Twenty-six Years Of Age; To Prohibit The Use Of Public Funds For Such Procedures; And To Create A Criminal Penalty For Violations, Provide For Professional Discipline, Allow A Private Right Of Action, And Authorize The Attorney General To Enforce The Chapter.
history: [{'date': '2023-01-18', 'action': 'Introduced and read first time', 'chamber': 'H', 'chamber_id': 85, 'importance': 1}, {'date': '2023-01-18', 'action': 'Referred to Committee on Judiciary', 'chamber': 'H', 'chamber_id': 85, 'importance': 1}]
text:
[b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'2023-2024 Bill 3730 Text of Previous Version (Jan. 18, 2023) - South Carolina Legislature Online
', b' 
', b'
', b'South Carolina General Assembly125th Session, 2023-2024Bill 3730Indicates Matter StrickenIndicates New Matter(Text matches printed bills. Document has been reformatted to meet World Wide Web specifications.)
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'A bill
', b'
', b'TO AMEND THE SOUTH CAROLINA CODE OF LAWS BY ENACTING THE "MILLSTONE ACT OF 2023"; AND BY ADDING CHAPTER 141 TO TITLE 44 SO AS TO PROHIBIT HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONALS FROM MAKING REFERRALS FOR OR PROVIDING GENDER-TRANSITION PROCEDURES OR SERVICES TO ANYONE UNDER TWENTY-SIX YEARS OF AGE; TO PROHIBIT THE USE OF PUBLIC FUNDS FOR SUCH PROCEDURES; and TO CREATE A CRIMINAL PENALTY FOR VIOLATions, PROVIDE FOR PROFESSIONAL DISCIPLINE, ALLOW A PRIVATE RIGHT OF ACTION, AND AUTHORIZE THE ATTORNEY GENERAL TO ENFORCE THE CHAPTER.
', b'
', b'Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina:
', b'
', b'SECTION 1.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0 This act may be cited as the "Millstone Act of 2023".
', b'
', b'SECTION 2.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0Title 44 of the S.C. Code is amended by adding:
', b'
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0CHAPTER 141
', b'
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0Millstone Act of 2023
', b'
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0Section 44-141-10.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0As used in this chapter:
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(1) "Biological sex" means the biological indication of male and female in the context of reproductive potential or capacity, such as sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, and nonambiguous internal and external genitalia present at birth, without regard to an individual's psychological, chosen, or subjective experience of gender.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(2) "Cross-sex hormones" means: 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(a) testosterone or other androgens given to biological females in amounts that are larger or more potent than would normally occur naturally in healthy biological sex females; and 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(b) estrogen given to biological males in amounts that are larger or more potent than would normally occur naturally in healthy biological sex males.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(3) "Gender" means the psychological, behavioral, social, and cultural aspects of being male or female.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(4) "Gender-reassignment surgery" means any medical or surgical service that seeks to surgically alter or remove healthy physical or anatomical characteristics or features that are typical for the individual's biological sex, in order to instill or create physiological or anatomical characteristics that resemble a sex different from the individual's biological sex including, but not limited to, genital or nongenital gender-reassignment surgery.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(5) "Gender transition" means the process in which a person goes from identifying with and living as a gender that corresponds to his or her biological sex to identifying with and living as a gender different from his or her biological sex, and may involve social, legal, or physical changes.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(6)(a) "Gender-transition procedures" means any medical or surgical service including, but not limited to, physician's services, inpatient and outpatient hospital services, or prescribed drugs related to gender transition that seeks to: 
', b"\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(i) alter or remove physical or anatomical characteristics or features that are typical for the individual's biological sex; or 
", b"\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(ii) instill or create physiological or anatomical characteristics that resemble a sex different from the individual's biological sex including, but not limited to, medical services that provide puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, or other mechanisms to promote the development of feminizing or masculinizing features in the opposite biological sex, or genital or nongenital gender-reassignment surgery performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition. 
", b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(b) Gender-transition procedures do not include: 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(i) services to persons born with a medically verifiable disorder of sex development, including a person with external biological sex characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous, such as those born with 46 XX chromosomes with virilization, 46 XY chromosomes with undervirilization, or having both ovarian and testicular tissue;
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(ii) services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a disorder of sexual development that the physician has determined through genetic or biochemical testing that the person does not have normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid hormone action;
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(iii) the treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has been caused by or exacerbated by the performance of gender-transition procedures, whether or not the gender-transition procedure was performed in accordance with state and federal law; or
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(iv) any procedure undertaken because the individual suffers from a physical disorder, physical injury, or physical illness that would, as certified by a physician, place the individual in imminent danger of death or impairment of major bodily function unless surgery is performed.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(7) "Genital gender-reassignment surgery" means a medical procedure performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition, including but not limited to: 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(a) surgical procedures such as penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, or vulvoplasty for biologically male patients or hysterectomy or oophorectomy for biologically female patients; 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(b) reconstruction of the fixed part of the urethra with or without a metoidioplasty; or 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(c) phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, or implantation of erection or testicular prostheses for biologically female patients.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(8) "Health care professional" means a person who is licensed, certified, or otherwise authorized by the laws of this State to administer health care in the ordinary course of the practice of the person's profession.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(9) "Nongenital gender-reassignment surgery" means medical procedures performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition including, but not limited to: 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(a) surgical procedures for biologically male patients, such as augmentation mammoplasty, facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, or various aesthetic procedures; or 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(b) surgical procedures for biologically female patients, such as subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, or various aesthetic procedures.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(10) "Physician" means a person who is licensed to practice medicine in this State.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(11) "Puberty-blocking drugs" means gonadotropin releasing hormone analogues or other synthetic drugs used in biological males to stop luteinizing hormone secretion and therefore testosterone secretion, or synthetic drugs used in biological females which stop the production of estrogen and progesterone, when used to delay or suppress pubertal development in children for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(12) "Public funds" means state, county, or local governmental monies, in addition to any department, agency, or instrumentality authorized or appropriated under state law or derived from any fund authorized or appropriated under state law or derived from any fund in which such monies are deposited.
', b'
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0Section 44-141-20.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(A) A physician or other health care professional shall not provide gender-transition procedures to any individual under twenty-six years of age.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(B) A physician or other health care professional shall not refer any individual under twenty-six years of age to any health care professional for gender-transition procedures.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(C) A physician or other health care professional is not prohibited from providing any of the following procedures which are not gender-transition procedures to an individual under twenty-six years of age:
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(1) services to persons born with a medically verifiable disorder of sex development, including a person with external biological sex characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous, such as those born with 46 XX chromosomes with virilization, 46 XY chromosomes with undervirilization, or having both ovarian and testicular tissue;
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(2) services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a disorder of sexual development that the physician has determined through genetic or biochemical testing that the person does not have normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid hormone action;
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(3) the treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has been caused by or exacerbated by the performance of gender-transition procedures, whether or not the gender-transition procedure was performed in accordance with state and federal law or whether or not funding for the gender-transition procedure is permissible under Section 44-141-30; or
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(4) any procedure undertaken because the individual suffers from a physical disorder, physical injury, or physical illness that would, as certified by a physician, place the individual in imminent danger of death or impairment of major bodily function unless surgery is performed.
', b'
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0Section 44-141-30.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(A) Public funds shall not be directly or indirectly used, granted, paid, or distributed to any entity, organization, or individual that provides gender-transition procedures to an individual under twenty-six years of age. 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(B) Health care services furnished in the following situations shall not include gender-transition procedures to an individual under twenty-six years of age: 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(1) by or in a health care facility owned by the State or a county or local government; or 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(2) by a physician or other health care professional employed by the State or a county or local government. 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(C) The state Medicaid program shall not reimburse or provide coverage for gender-transition procedures to an individual under twenty-six years of age. 
', b'
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0Section 44-141-40.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(A)(1) A physician or other health care professional found to have knowingly referred for or provided gender-transition procedures to an individual under twenty-six years of age is guilty of a felony and, upon conviction, may be imprisoned not more than five years.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(2) Prosecution for a criminal violation of this subsection must be commenced within forty years after the commission of such offense.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(B)(1) Any referral for or provision of gender-transition procedures to an individual under twenty-six years of age is unprofessional conduct and shall, upon an adverse ruling by the appropriate licensing board, result in immediate revocation of the license or certificate of the physician or other health care professional.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(2) Disciplinary proceedings against the physician or other health care professional must be commenced within forty years after the commission of such offense. 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(C)(1) A person may assert an actual or threatened violation of this chapter as a claim or defense in a judicial or administrative proceeding and obtain compensatory damages, injunctive relief, declaratory relief, or any other appropriate relief. 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(2) A person shall bring a claim for a violation of this chapter no later than forty years after the day the cause of action accrues. 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(3) An individual under eighteen years of age may bring an action throughout their minority through a parent or next friend, and may bring an action in their own name upon reaching majority at any time from that point until forty years after reaching the age of majority. 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(4) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an action under this subsection may be commenced, and relief may be granted, in a judicial proceeding without regard to whether the person commencing the action has sought or exhausted available administrative remedies. 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(5) In any action or proceeding to enforce a provision of this chapter, a prevailing party who establishes a violation of this chapter shall recover reasonable attorney fees.
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(D)(1) The Attorney General may bring an action to enforce compliance with this chapter. 
', b'\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(2) This chapter does not deny, impair, or otherwise affect any right or authority of the Attorney General, this State, or any agency, officer, or employee of the State, acting under any law other than this act, to institute or intervene in any proceeding.
', b'
', b'SECTION 3.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0The repeal or amendment by this act of any law, whether temporary or permanent or civil or criminal, does not affect pending actions, rights, duties, or liabilities founded thereon, or alter, discharge, release or extinguish any penalty, forfeiture, or liability incurred under the repealed or amended law, unless the repealed or amended provision shall so expressly provide.\xc2\xa0 After the effective date of this act, all laws repealed or amended by this act must be taken and treated as remaining in full force and effect for the purpose of sustaining any pending or vested right, civil action, special proceeding, criminal prosecution, or appeal existing as of the effective date of this act, and for the enforcement of rights, duties, penalties, forfeitures, and liabilities as they stood under the repealed or amended laws.
', b'
', b'SECTION 4.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0This act takes effect upon approval by the Governor.
', b'----XX----
', b'This web page was last updated on January 18, 2023 at 02:50 PM
', b'
', b'
']

title: Child removal and gender identity.
description: Child removal and gender identity. Provides that the department of child services may not classify a report of child abuse or neglect as substantiated, and a child may not be removed from the child's parent, guardian, or custodian, solely on the basis of the parent, guardian, or custodian: (1) referring to and raising the child consistent with the child's biological sex; or (2) declining to consent to the child receiving: (A) specified medication; (B) a medical procedure the purpose of which is to alter the apparent gender or sex of the child or affirm the child's perception of the child's gender or sex in a manner inconsistent with the child's biological sex; or (C) counseling or other mental health services the purpose of which is to affirm the child's perception of the child's gender or sex if the child's perception is inconsistent with the child's biological sex.

title: Oklahoma Save Adolescents from Experimentation (SAFE) Act; effective date.

', b'BE IT ENACTED BY THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF OKLAHOMA:  
', b'SECTION 1.     NEW LAW     A new section of law to be codified 
', b'in the O klahoma Statutes as Section 2606 of Title 63, unless there 
', b'is created a d uplication in nu mbering, reads as follows:  
', b'This act sh all be known and may be cited as the "Oklahoma Save

', b'SECTION 2.     NEW LAW     A new section of law to be codified 
', b'in the Oklahoma Statutes as Section 2607 of Title 63, unless there 
', b'is created a duplication in numbering, reads as follows:  
', b'A.  As used in this sect ion: 
', b'1.  "Biological sex " means the biological indication of  male and 
', b'female in the con text of reprod uctive potential or capacity, su ch as

', b'given to biological females in amounts that are larger or more
