title: Gender reassignment
description: Amend The South Carolina Code Of Laws By Adding Section 40-47-205, Relating To General Provisions Concerning Physicians, So As To Prohibit Physicians From Performing Gender Reassignment Surgery On Minors, And To Prohibit Physicians From Prescribing Or Administering Certain Substances For The Purpose Of Attempting To Alter The Appearance Of Or Affirm The Minor's Perception Of His Gender If That Appearance Or Perception Is Inconsistent With The Minor's Biological Sex.
history: [{'date': '2022-11-30', 'action': 'Prefiled', 'chamber': 'S', 'chamber_id': 86, 'importance': 0}, {'date': '2022-11-30', 'action': 'Referred to Committee on Medical Affairs', 'chamber': 'S', 'chamber_id': 86, 'importance': 0}, {'date': '2023-01-10', 'action': 'Introduced and read first time', 'chamber': 'S', 'chamber_id': 86, 'importance': 1}, {'date': '2023-01-10', 'action': 'Referred to Committee on Medical Affairs', 'chamber': 'S', 'chamber_id': 86, 'importance': 1}]
text:
[b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'2023-2024 Bill 243 Text of Previous Version (Dec. 02, 2022) - South Carolina Legislature Online
', b' 
', b'
', b'South Carolina General Assembly125th Session, 2023-2024Bill 243Indicates Matter StrickenIndicates New Matter(Text matches printed bills. Document has been reformatted to meet World Wide Web specifications.)
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'
', b'A bill
', b'
', b'to amend the South Carolina Code of Laws by adding Section 40-47-205, RELATING TO GENERAL PROVISIONS CONCERNING PHYSICIANS, so as to PROHIBIT PHYSICIANS FROM PERFORMING GENDER REASSIGNMENT SURGERY ON MINORS, AND TO PROHIBIT PHYSICIANS FROM PRESCRIBING OR ADMINISTERING CERTAIN SUBSTANCES FOR THE PURPOSE OF ATTEMPTING TO ALTER THE APPEARANCE OF OR AFFIRM THE MINOR\xe2\x80\x99S PERCEPTION OF HIS GENDER IF THAT APPEARANCE OR PERCEPTION IS INCONSISTENT WITH THE MINOR\xe2\x80\x99S BIOLOGICAL SEX.
', b'
', b'Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina:
', b'
', b'SECTION 1.	Article 1, Chapter 47, Title 40 of the S.C. Code is amended by adding:
', b'
', b' Section 4047205.	(A) For the purposes of this section:
', b'  (1) \xe2\x80\x9cBiological sex\xe2\x80\x9d means the biological indication of male and female in the context of reproductive potential or capacity, such as sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads and nonambiguous internal and external genitalia present at birth, without regard to an individual\xe2\x80\x99s psychological, chosen, or subjective experience of gender.
', b'  (2) \xe2\x80\x9cGender\xe2\x80\x9d means the psychological, behavioral, social, and cultural aspects of being male or female.
', b'  (3) \xe2\x80\x9cGender transition\xe2\x80\x9d means the process in which a person goes from identifying with and living as a gender that corresponds to the person\xe2\x80\x99s biological sex to identifying with and living as a gender different from the person\xe2\x80\x99s biological sex and may involve social, legal, or physical changes.
', b'  (4) \xe2\x80\x9cIrreversible gender reassignment surgery\xe2\x80\x9d means a medical procedure performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition, including, but not limited to:
', b'   (a) penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, or vulvoplasty for biologically male patients or hysterectomy or ovariectomy for biologically female patients;
', b'   (b) metoidioplasty, phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, or implantation of erection or testicular prostheses for biologically female patients; and
', b'   (c) augmentation mammoplasty for biologically male patients and subcutaneous mastectomy for female patients.
', b' (B) A physician may not provide irreversible reassignment surgery to a minor.
', b' (C) A physician may not prescribe or administer puberty blocking medication to stop or delay normal puberty, supraphysiologic doses of testosterone or other androgens to females, or supraphysiologic doses of estrogen to males for the purpose of attempting to alter the appearance of or affirm the minor\xe2\x80\x99s perception of his gender if that appearance or perception is inconsistent with the minor\xe2\x80\x99s biological sex.
', b' (D) A physician may provide to a minor:
', b'  (1) services to a minor born with a medically verifiable disorder of sex development, including, but not limited to, an individual with external biological sex characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous;
', b'  (2) services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a disorder of sexual development and has determined through genetic or biochemical testing that the individual does not have normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production or sex steroid hormone action;
', b'  (3) treatment for an infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has been caused or exacerbated by the performance of a gender transition procedure, whether or not the gender transition procedure was performed in accordance with state or federal law; and
', b'  (4) any procedure undertaken because the minor suffers from a physical disorder, physical injury, or physical illness that would place the individual in imminent danger of death or the impairment of a major bodily function unless surgery is performed.
', b'
', b'SECTION 2.	This act takes effect upon approval by the Governor.
', b'XX
', b'----XX----This web page was last updated on December 02, 2022 at 10:27 AM
', b'
', b'
']

title: Enacting the protecting children's bodies act.
description: Enacting the protecting children's bodies act.
history: [{'date': '2023-01-10', 'action': 'First reading, referred to Health Care & Wellness.', 'chamber': 'H', 'chamber_id': 97, 'importance': 1}]
text:
[b"AN ACT Relating to enacting the protecting children's bodies act; 1
", b'amending RCW 48.43.0128  and 74.09.675 ; adding a new section to 2
', b'chapter 43.70  RCW ; creating a new section; and prescribing penalties. 3
', b'BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON: 4
', b'NEW SECTION.   Sec. 1.  A new section is added to chapter 43.70 5
', b'RCW to read as follows: 6
', b'(1) A health care provider may not provide gender transition 7
', b'procedures to any individual who is under 18 years of age. A health 8
', b'care provider may not refer any individual who is under 18 years of 9
', b'age to any health care provider for gender transition procedures. A 10
', b'health care provider is not prohibited from providing any of the 11
', b'following procedures that are not gender transition procedures to an 12
', b'individual who is under 18 years of age: 13
', b'(a) Services to persons born with a medically verifiable disorder 14
', b'of sex development, including a person with external biological sex 15
', b'characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous, such as being born 16
', b'with 46 xx chromosomes with virilization or 46 xy chromosomes with 17
', b'undervirilization or having both ovarian and testicular tissue; 18
', b'(b) Services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a 19
', b'disorder of sexual development and has determined through genetic or 20
', b'biochemical testing that the person does not have normal sex 21H-0367.2
', b'HOUSE BILL 1214
', b'State of Washington 68th Legislature 2023 Regular Session
', b'By Representative Walsh
', b'p. 1 HB 1214chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid 1
', b'hormone action; 2
', b'(c) The treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder 3
', b'that has been caused by or exacerbated by the performance of gender 4
', b'transition procedures, whether or not the gender transition procedure 5
', b'was performed in accordance with state and federal law or whether or 6
', b'not funding for the gender transition procedure is allowable under 7
', b'this section; and 8
', b'(d) Any procedure undertaken because the individual suffers from 9
', b'a physical disorder, physical injury, or physical illness that would, 10
', b'as certified by a physician, place the individual in imminent danger 11
', b'of death or impairment of major bodily function unless surgery is 12
', b'performed. 13
', b'(2) Public funds may not be directly or indirectly used, granted, 14
', b'paid, or distributed to any entity, organization, or individual that 15
', b'provides gender transition procedures to an individual who is under 16
', b'18 years of age. Health care services furnished in the following 17
', b'situations may not include gender transition procedures to an 18
', b'individual who is under 18 years of age: 19
', b'(a) By or in a health care facility owned by this state or a 20
', b'county or local government; and 21
', b'(b) By a health care provider employed by the state or a county 22
', b'or local government. 23
', b'(3) Any referral for or provision of gender transition procedures 24
', b'to an individual who is under 18 years of age is unprofessional 25
', b'conduct and is subject to discipline by the appropriate disciplining 26
', b'authority. 27
', b'(4) A person may assert an actual or threatened violation of this 28
', b'section as a claim or defense in a judicial or administrative 29
', b'proceeding and obtain compensatory damages, injunctive relief, 30
', b'declaratory relief, or any other appropriate relief. A person must 31
', b'bring a claim for a violation of this section no later than two years 32
', b'after the day the cause of action accrues. An individual who is under 33
', b"18 years of age may bring an action throughout the individual's 34
", b'minority through a parent or next friend and may bring an action in 35
', b"the individual's own name on reaching 18 years of age until 20 years 36
", b'after reaching 18 years of age. 37
', b'(5) Notwithstanding any other law, an action under this section 38
', b'may be commenced, and relief may be granted, in a judicial proceeding 39
', b'without regard to whether the person commencing the action has sought 40
', b'p. 2 HB 1214or exhausted available administrative remedies. In any action or 1
', b'proceeding to enforce this section, a prevailing party who 2
', b'establishes a violation of this section shall recover reasonable 3
', b'attorney fees. 4
', b'(6) The attorney general may bring an action to enforce 5
', b'compliance with this section. This section does not deny, impair, or 6
', b'otherwise affect any right or authority of the attorney general, this 7
', b'state, or any agency, officer, or employee of this state, acting 8
', b'under any law other than this section, to institute or intervene in 9
', b'any proceeding. 10
', b'(7) A violation of this section is a class C felony. 11
', b'(8) For the purposes of this section: 12
', b'(a) "Biological sex" means the biological indication of male and 13
', b'female in the context of reproductive potential or capacity, such as 14
', b'sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads and 15
', b'nonambiguous internal and external genitalia present at birth, 16
', b"without regard to an individual's psychological, chosen, or 17
", b'subjective experience of gender. 18
', b'(b) "Cross-sex hormones" means either of the following: 19
', b'(i) Testosterone or other androgens given to biological females 20
', b'in amounts that are larger or more potent than would normally occur 21
', b'naturally in healthy biological sex females; or 22
', b'(ii)  Estrogen given to biological males in amounts that are 23
', b'larger or more potent than would normally occur naturally in healthy 24
', b'biological sex males. 25
', b'(c) "Gender" means the psychological, behavioral, social, and 26
', b'cultural aspects of being male or female. 27
', b'(d) "Gender reassignment surgery" means any medical or surgical 28
', b'service that seeks to surgically alter or remove healthy physical or 29
', b'anatomical characteristics or features that are typical for an 30
', b"individual's biological sex in order to instill or create 31
", b'physiological or anatomical characteristics that resemble a sex 32
', b'different from the individual's biological sex. "Gender reassignment 33
', b'surgery" includes genital or nongenital gender reassignment surgery 34
', b'performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender 35
', b'transition. 36
', b'(e) "Gender transition" means the process in which a person goes 37
', b'from identifying with and living as a gender that corresponds to the 38
', b"person's biological sex to identifying with and living as a gender 39
", b"p. 3 HB 1214different from the person's biological sex and may involve social, 1
", b'legal, or physical changes. 2
', b'(f) "Gender transition procedures": 3
', b'(i) Means any medical or surgical service, including physician 4
', b'services, inpatient and outpatient hospital services, or prescribed 5
', b'drugs related to gender transition, that seeks to either: 6
', b'(A) Alter or remove physical or anatomical characteristics or 7
', b"features that are typical for the individual's biological sex; or 8
", b'(B) Instill or create physiological or anatomical characteristics 9
', b"that resemble a sex different from the individual's biological sex, 10
", b'including medical services that provide puberty-blocking drugs, 11
', b'cross-sex hormones, or other mechanisms to promote the development of 12
', b'feminizing or masculinizing features in the opposite biological sex 13
', b'or genital or nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed for 14
', b'the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition. 15
', b'(ii)  Does not include any of the following: 16
', b'(A) Services to persons born with a medically verifiable disorder 17
', b'of sex development, including a person with external biological sex 18
', b'characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous, such as being born 19
', b'with 46 xx chromosomes with virilization or 46 xy chromosomes with 20
', b'undervirilization or having both ovarian and testicular tissue; 21
', b'(B) Services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a 22
', b'disorder of sexual development and has determined through genetic or 23
', b'biochemical testing that the person does not have normal sex 24
', b'chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid 25
', b'hormone action; 26
', b'(C) The treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder 27
', b'that has been caused by or exacerbated by the performance of gender 28
', b'transition procedures, whether or not the gender transition procedure 29
', b'was performed in accordance with state and federal law or whether or 30
', b'not funding for the gender transition procedure is allowable under 31
', b'this section; and 32
', b'(D) Any procedure undertaken because the individual suffers from 33
', b'a physical disorder, physical injury, or physical illness that would, 34
', b'as certified by a physician, place the individual in imminent danger 35
', b'of death or impairment of major bodily function unless surgery is 36
', b'performed. 37
', b'(g) "Genital gender reassignment surgery" means a medical 38
', b'procedure performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a 39
', b'gender transition, including any of the following: 40
', b'p. 4 HB 1214(i) Surgical procedures such as penectomy, orchiectomy, 1
', b'vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, or vulvoplasty for biologically male 2
', b'patients or hysterectomy or ovariectomy for biologically female 3
', b'patients; 4
', b'(ii)  Reconstruction of the fixed part of the urethra with or 5
', b'without a metoidioplasty; 6
', b'(iii)  Phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, or implantation of 7
', b'erection or testicular prostheses for biologically female patients; 8
', b'and 9
', b'(iv)  Removing any healthy or nondiseased body part. 10
', b'(h) "Health care provider" means a person regulated under Title 11
', b'18 RCW to practice health or health-related services or otherwise 12
', b'practicing health care services in this state consistent with state 13
', b'law. 14
', b'(i) "Nongenital gender reassignment surgery" means medical 15
', b'procedures performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with 16
', b'a gender transition, including either of the following: 17
', b'(i) Surgical procedures for biologically male patients, such as 18
', b'augmentation mammoplasty, facial feminization surgery, liposuction, 19
', b'lipofilling, voice surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal 20
', b'augmentation, hair reconstruction, or various aesthetic procedures; 21
', b'and 22
', b'(ii)  Surgical procedures for biologically female patients, such 23
', b'as subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, 24
', b'pectoral implants, or various aesthetic procedures. 25
', b'(j) "Puberty-blocking drugs" means gonadotropin-releasing hormone 26
', b'analogues or other synthetic drugs used in biological males to stop 27
', b'luteinizing hormone secretion and testosterone secretion, or 28
', b'synthetic drugs used in biological females which stop the production 29
', b'of estrogens and progesterone, when used to delay or suppress 30
', b'pubertal development in children for the purpose of assisting an 31
', b'individual with a gender transition. 32
', b'(k) "Public funds" means state, county, or local government 33
', b'moneys, in addition to any department, agency, or instrumentality 34
', b'authorized or appropriated under state law or derived from any fund 35
', b'in which such moneys are deposited. 36
', b'Sec. 2.  RCW 48.43.0128  and 2021 c 280 s 3 are each amended to 37
', b'read as follows: 38
', b'p. 5 HB 1214(1) A health carrier offering a nongrandfathered health plan or a 1
', b'plan deemed by the commissioner to have a short-term limited purpose 2
', b'or duration, or to be a student-only plan that is guaranteed 3
', b'renewable while the covered person is enrolled as a regular, full- 4
', b'time undergraduate student at an accredited higher education 5
', b'institution may not: 6
', b'(a) In its benefit design or implementation of its benefit 7
', b'design, discriminate against individuals because of their age, 8
', b'expected length of life, present or predicted disability, degree of 9
', b'medical dependency, quality of life, or other health conditions; and 10
', b'(b) With respect to the health plan or plan deemed by the 11
', b'commissioner to have a short-term limited purpose or duration, or to 12
', b'be a student-only plan that is guaranteed renewable while the covered 13
', b'person is enrolled as a regular, full-time undergraduate student at 14
', b'an accredited higher education institution, discriminate on the basis 15
', b'of race, color, national origin, disability, age, sex, gender 16
', b'identity, or sexual orientation. 17
', b'(2) Nothing in this section may be construed to prevent a carrier 18
', b'from appropriately utilizing reasonable medical management 19
', b'techniques. 20
', b'(3) ((For)) Except as provided in subsection (9) of this section, 21
', b'for health plans issued or renewed on or after January 1, 2022: 22
', b'(a) A health carrier may not deny or limit coverage for gender 23
', b'affirming treatment when that treatment is prescribed to an 24
', b"individual because of, related to, or consistent with a person's 25
", b'gender expression or identity, as defined in RCW 49.60.040 , is 26
', b'medically necessary, and is prescribed in accordance with accepted 27
', b'standards of care. 28
', b'(b) A health carrier may not apply categorical cosmetic or 29
', b'blanket exclusions to gender affirming treatment. When prescribed as 30
', b'medically necessary gender affirming treatment, a health carrier may 31
', b'not exclude as cosmetic services facial feminization surgeries and 32
', b'other facial gender affirming treatment, such as tracheal shaves, 33
', b'hair electrolysis, and other care such as mastectomies, breast 34
', b'reductions, breast implants, or any combination of gender affirming 35
', b'procedures, including revisions to prior treatment. 36
', b'(c) A health carrier may not issue an adverse benefit 37
', b'determination denying or limiting access to gender affirming 38
', b'services, unless a health care provider with experience prescribing 39
', b'p. 6 HB 1214or delivering gender affirming treatment has reviewed and confirmed 1
', b'the appropriateness of the adverse benefit determination. 2
', b'(d) Health carriers must comply with all network access rules and 3
', b'requirements established by the commissioner. 4
', b'(4) For the purposes of this section, "gender affirming 5
', b'treatment" means a service or product that a health care provider, as 6
', b'defined in RCW 70.02.010 , prescribes to an individual to treat any 7
', b"condition related to the individual's gender identity and is 8
", b'prescribed in accordance with generally accepted standards of care. 9
', b'Gender affirming treatment must be covered in a manner compliant with 10
', b'the federal mental health parity and addiction equity act of 2008 and 11
', b'the federal affordable care act. Gender affirming treatment can be 12
', b'prescribed to two spirit, transgender, nonbinary, intersex, and other 13
', b'gender diverse individuals. 14
', b'(5) Nothing in this section may be construed to mandate coverage 15
', b'of a service that is not medically necessary. 16
', b'(6) By December 1, 2022, the commissioner, in consultation with 17
', b'the health care authority and the department of health, must issue a 18
', b'report on geographic access to gender affirming treatment across the 19
', b'state. The report must include the number of gender affirming 20
', b'providers offering care in each county, the carriers and medicaid 21
', b'managed care organizations those providers have active contracts 22
', b'with, and the types of services provided by each provider in each 23
', b'region. The commissioner must update the report biannually and post 24
', b'the report on its website. 25
', b'(7) The commissioner shall adopt any rules necessary to implement 26
', b'subsections (3), (4), and (5) of this section. 27
', b'(8) Unless preempted by federal law, the commissioner shall adopt 28
', b'any rules necessary to implement subsections (1) and (2) of this 29
', b'section, consistent with federal rules and guidance in effect on 30
', b'January 1, 2017, implementing the patient protection and affordable 31
', b'care act. 32
', b'(9) A health carrier may not reimburse or provide coverage for 33
', b'gender affirming treatment to an individual who is under 18 years of 34
', b'age. 35
', b'Sec. 3.  RCW 74.09.675  and 2021 c 280 s 4 are each amended to 36
', b'read as follows: 37
', b'(1) ((In)) Except as provided in subsection (6) of this section, 38
', b'in the provision of gender affirming care services through programs 39
', b'p. 7 HB 1214under this chapter, the authority, managed care plans, and providers 1
', b'that administer or deliver such services may not discriminate in the 2
', b'delivery of a service provided through a program of the authority 3
', b"based on the covered person's gender identity or expression. 4
", b'(2) ((Beginning )) Except as provided in subsection (6) of this 5
', b'section, beginning  January 1, 2022: 6
', b'(a) The authority and any managed care plans delivering or 7
', b'administering services purchased or contracted for by the authority 8
', b'may not apply categorical cosmetic or blanket exclusions to gender 9
', b'affirming treatment. 10
', b'(b) Facial feminization surgeries and facial gender affirming 11
', b'treatment, such as tracheal shaves, hair electrolysis, and other care 12
', b'such as mastectomies, breast reductions, breast implants, or any 13
', b'combination of gender affirming procedures, including revisions to 14
', b'prior treatment, when prescribed as gender affirming treatment, may 15
', b'not be excluded as cosmetic. 16
', b'(c) The authority and managed care plans administering services 17
', b'purchased or contracted for by the authority may not issue an adverse 18
', b'benefit determination denying or limiting access to gender affirming 19
', b'treatment, unless a health care provider with experience prescribing 20
', b'or delivering gender affirming treatment has reviewed and confirmed 21
', b'the appropriateness of the adverse benefit determination. 22
', b'(d) If the authority and managed care plans administering 23
', b'services purchased or contracted for by the authority do not have an 24
', b'adequate network for gender affirming treatment, they shall ensure 25
', b'the delivery of timely and geographically accessible medically 26
', b'necessary gender affirming treatment at no greater expense than if 27
', b'they had an in-network, geographically accessible provider available. 28
', b'This includes, but is not limited to, providing case management 29
', b'services to secure out-of-network gender affirming treatment options 30
', b'that are available to the enrollee in a timely manner within their 31
', b'geographic region. The enrollee shall pay no more than the same cost 32
', b'sharing that the enrollee would pay for the same covered services 33
', b'received from an in-network provider. 34
', b'(3) For the purposes of this section, "gender affirming 35
', b'treatment" means a service or product that a health care provider, as 36
', b'defined in RCW 70.02.010 , prescribes to an individual to support and 37
', b"affirm the individual's gender identity. Gender affirming treatment 38
", b'includes, but is not limited to, treatment for gender dysphoria. 39
', b'p. 8 HB 1214Gender affirming treatment can be prescribed to two spirit, 1
', b'transgender, nonbinary, and other gender diverse individuals. 2
', b'(4) Nothing in this section may be construed to mandate coverage 3
', b'of a service that is not medically necessary. 4
', b'(5) The authority shall adopt rules necessary to implement this 5
', b'section. 6
', b'(6) The authority and managed care plans administering services 7
', b'purchased or contracted for by the authority may not reimburse or 8
', b'provide coverage for gender affirming treatment to an individual who 9
', b'is under 18 years of age. 10
', b'NEW SECTION.   Sec. 4.  This act may be known and cited as the 11
', b"protecting children's bodies act. 12
", b'--- END ---
', b'p. 9 HB 1214']

title: Establishes guidelines for student participation in athletic contests organized by sex

text:
[b'FIRST REGULAR SESSION
', b'HOUSE BILL NO. 183 102ND GENERAL ASSEMBLY
', b'INTRODUCED BY REPRESENTATIVE BURGER.
', b'DANA RADEMAN MILLER, Chief Clerk
', b'AN ACT
', b'    2
', b'2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9
', b'10
', b'11
', b'12
', b'13
', b'14
', b'15
', b'16
', b'17
', b'To amend chapter 163, RSMo, by adding thereto one new section relating to participation in athletic competitions.
', b'Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the state of Missouri, as follows:
', b'Section A. Chapter 163, RSMo, is amended by adding thereto one new section, to be known as section 163.048, to read as follows:
', b'163.048. 1. As used in this section, the following terms mean:
', b'(1) "Athletics", any interscholastic athletic games, contests, programs, activities, exhibitions, or other similar competitions organized and provided for students;
', b'(2) "Sex", the two main categories of male and female into which individuals are divided based on an individual's reproductive biology at birth and the individual's genome.
', b'2. (1) The general assembly hereby finds the following:
', b'(a) A noticeable disparity continues between the athletics participation rates of students who are male and students who are female;
', b'(b) Courts have recognized a legitimate and important governmental interest in redressing past discrimination against females in athletics on the basis of sex and promoting equality of athletic opportunity between the sexes under Title IX of the federal Education Amendments of 1972 (20 U.S.C. Section 1681 et seq.), as amended; and
', b'(c) Courts have recognized that classification by sex is the only feasible classification to promote the governmental interest of providing opportunities for athletics for females.
', b'EXPLANATION \xe2\x80\x94 Matter enclosed in bold-faced brackets [thus] in the above bill is not enacted and is intended to be omitted from the law. Matter in bold-face type in the above bill is proposed language.
', b'HB 183 2
', b'18
', b'19
', b'20
', b'21
', b'22
', b'23
', b'24
', b'25
', b'26
', b'27
', b'28
', b'29
', b'30
', b'31
', b'32
', b'33
', b'34
', b'35
', b'36
', b'37
', b'38
', b'39
', b'40
', b'41
', b'42
', b'43
', b'44
', b'45
', b'46
', b'47
', b'48
', b'(2) The general assembly hereby declares that it is the public policy of this state to further the governmental interest of ensuring that sufficient opportunities for athletics remain available for females to remedy past discrimination on the basis of sex.
', b"3. (1) Except as provided under subdivision (2) of this subsection, no school district or charter school shall allow any student to compete in an athletics competition that is designated for the biological sex opposite to the student's biological sex as correctly stated on the student's official birth certificate as described in subsection 4 of this section or, if the student's official birth certificate is unobtainable, another government record.
", b'(2) A school district or charter school may allow a female student to compete in an athletics competition that is designated for male students if no corresponding athletics competition designated for female students is offered or available.
', b"4. For purposes of this section, a statement of a student's biological sex on the student's official birth certificate or another government record shall be deemed to have correctly stated the student's biological sex only if the statement was:
", b"(1) Entered at or near the time of the student's birth; or
", b"(2) Modified to correct any scrivener's error in the student's biological sex.
", b'5. No school district or charter school that violates subdivision (1) of subsection 3
', b'of this section shall receive any state aid under this chapter or any other revenues from the state.
', b'6. The department of elementary and secondary education shall promulgate all necessary rules and regulations for the implementation and administration of this section. Such rules and regulations shall ensure compliance with state and federal law regarding the confidentiality of student medical information. Any rule or portion of a rule, as that term is defined in section 536.010, that is created under the authority delegated in this section shall become effective only if it complies with and is subject to all of the provisions of chapter 536 and, if applicable, section 536.028. This section and chapter 536 are nonseverable and if any of the powers vested with the general assembly pursuant to chapter 536 to review, to delay the effective date, or to disapprove and annul a rule are subsequently held unconstitutional, then the grant of rulemaking authority and any rule proposed or adopted after August 28, 2023, shall be invalid and void.
', b'\xe2\x9c\x94']

title: A concurrent resolution urging public schools and public entities, including agencies or departments that collect vital statistics, to protect women's rights by distinguishing between the sexes according to biological sex at birth for the purpose of providing equal opportunities and ensuring the privacy and safety of women and girls.
description: A concurrent resolution urging public schools and public entities, including agencies or departments that collect vital statistics, to protect women's rights by distinguishing between the sexes according to biological sex at birth for the purpose of providing equal opportunities and ensuring the privacy and safety of women and girls.

text:
[b'23.3027.02000
', b'Sixty-eighth
', b'Legislative Assembly
', b'of North Dakota
', b'Introduced by
', b'Representatives S. Olson, K. Anderson, Henderson, Meier, Novak, Rohr, Steiner, VanWinkle
', b'A concurrent resolution urging public schools and public entities, including agencies or  
', b"departments that collect vital statistics, to protect women's rights by distinguishing between the  
", b'sexes according to biological sex at birth for the purpose of providing equal opportunities and  
', b'ensuring the privacy and safety of women and girls.
', b'WHEREAS, a male and a female possess unique and immutable biological differences that  
', b'manifest prior to birth and increase as the individual ages and experiences puberty; and
', b'WHEREAS, biological differences between the sexes mean that only a female is able to  
', b'become pregnant, give birth, and breastfeed children; and
', b'WHEREAS, biological differences between the sexes mean that a male is, on average,  
', b'bigger, stronger, and faster than a female; and
', b'WHEREAS, biological differences between the sexes leave a female more physically  
', b'vulnerable than a male to specific forms of violence, including sexual violence; and
', b'WHEREAS, females have suffered historically from discrimination in education, athletics,  
', b'and employment; and
', b'WHEREAS, when it comes to sex, "equal" does not mean "same" or "identical" and  
', b'separate is not inherently unequal; and
', b'WHEREAS, biological differences between the sexes are enduring and may warrant the  
', b'creation of separate social, educational, athletic, or other spaces to ensure safety or allow  
', b'members of each sex to succeed and thrive; and
', b'WHEREAS, inconsistencies in court rulings and policy initiatives with respect to the  
', b'definitions of "sex", "male", "female", "man", and "woman" have led to endangerment of  
', b'single-sex spaces and resources, thereby necessitating clarification of certain terms; and
', b'WHEREAS, there are legitimate reasons to distinguish between the sexes with respect to  
', b'athletics, prisons and other detention facilities, domestic violence shelters, rape and abuse  
', b'Page No. 1 23.3027.02000 HOUSE CONCURRENT RESOLUTION NO. 3010    
', b'1
', b'2
', b'3
', b'4
', b'5
', b'6
', b'7
', b'8
', b'9
', b'10
', b'11
', b'12
', b'13
', b'14
', b'15
', b'16
', b'17
', b'18
', b'19
', b'20
', b'21
', b'22
', b'23
', b'24Sixty-eighth
', b'Legislative Assembly
', b'crisis centers, locker rooms, restrooms, and other areas where safety and privacy are  
', b'implicated; and
', b'WHEREAS, policies and laws that distinguish between the sexes are subject to  
', b'intermediate constitutional scrutiny, which forbids unfair discrimination against similarly situated  
', b'males and females but allows the law to distinguish between the sexes if distinctions are  
', b'substantially related to important governmental objectives;
', b'NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES OF  
', b'NORTH DAKOTA, THE SENATE CONCURRING THEREIN:
', b'That the Sixty-eighth Legislative Assembly urges public schools and public entities,  
', b"including agencies or departments that collect vital statistics, to protect women's rights by  
", b'distinguishing between the sexes according to biological sex at birth for the purpose of  
', b'providing equal opportunities and ensuring the privacy and safety of women and girls; and
', b'BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED , that the Secretary of State forward a copy of this resolution  
', b'to the Superintendent of Public Instruction, the superintendent of each school district in the  
', b'state, and the Executive Director of the Department of Health and Human Services.
', b'Page No. 2 23.3027.020001

text:
[b' 
', b'EXPLANATION -Matter enclosed in bold -faced brackets [thus] in this bill is not enacted 
', b'and is intended to be omitted in the law.  FIRST REGULAR SESSION  
', b'SENATE BILL NO. 164  
', b'102ND GENERAL ASSEMBLY   
', b'INTRODUCED BY SENATOR CARTER.  
', b'1196S.01I  KRISTINA MARTIN, Secretary   
', b'AN ACT  
', b'To repeal section 568.060, RSMo, and to enact in lieu thereof two new sections relating to gender 
', b'transition procedures, with existing penalty provisions.  
', b' 
', b'Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Missouri, as follows:  
', b'     Section A.  Section 568.060, RSMo, is repealed and two new 1 
', b'sections enacted in lieu thereof, to be known as sections 2 
', b'191.1720 and 568.060, to read as follows: 3 
', b'     191.1720.   1.  This section shall be known and may be  1 
', b'cited as the "Missouri Save Adolescents from Experimentation  2 
', b'(SAFE) Act".  3 
', b'     2.  For purposes of this section, the following terms  4 
', b'mean: 5 
', b'     (1)  "Biological sex", the bi ological indication of the  6 
', b'physical condition of being male or female, which is  7 
', b"determined by a person's chromosomes, identified at birth by  8 
", b"a person's anatomy, and indicated on their birth  9 
", b"certificate, without regard to an individual's  10 
", b'psychological,  chosen, or subjective experience of gender;  11 
', b'     (2)  "Cross-sex hormones":  12 
', b'     (a)  Testosterone or other androgens given to  13 
', b'biological sex females in amounts that are larger or more  14 
', b'potent than would normally occur naturally in healthy  15 
', b'biological se x females; and  16  SB 164  2 
', b'     (b)  Estrogen given to biological sex males in amounts  17 
', b'that are larger or more potent than would normally occur  18 
', b'naturally in healthy biological sex males;  19 
', b'     (3)  "Gender", the psychological, behavioral, social,  20 
', b'and cultural aspect s of being male or female;  21 
', b'     (4)  "Gender reassignment surgery", any medical or  22 
', b'surgical service that alters or removes physical or  23 
', b"anatomical characteristics of an individual's biological sex  24 
", b'for the purpose of gender transition;  25 
', b'     (5)  "Gender t ransition", the process in which an  26 
', b'individual transitions from his or her biological sex to a  27 
', b'gender different from his or her biological sex, which may  28 
', b'involve social, legal, or physical changes;  29 
', b'     (6)  "Gender transition procedures":  30 
', b'     (a)  Any medical or surgical service, including, but  31 
', b"not limited to, physician's services, inpatient and  32 
", b'outpatient hospital services, or prescribed drugs, related  33 
', b'to gender transition that seeks to:  34 
', b'     a.  Alter or remove physical or anatomical  35 
', b'characterist ics or features that are typical for the  36 
', b"individual's biological sex; or  37 
", b'     b.  Instill or create physiological or anatomical  38 
', b'characteristics that resemble a sex different from the  39 
', b"individual's biological sex, including, but not limited to:  40 
", b'     (i)  Medical services that provide puberty -blocking  41 
', b'drugs, cross -sex hormones, or other mechanisms to promote  42 
', b'the development of feminizing or masculinizing features in  43 
', b'the opposite biological sex; or  44 
', b'     (ii)  Genital or nongenital gender reassignment surg ery  45 
', b'performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a  46 
', b'gender transition;  47  SB 164  3 
', b'     (b)  The term "gender transition procedures" shall not  48 
', b'include:  49 
', b'     a.  Services to individuals born with medically - 50 
', b'verifiable disorders of sex development, includ ing  51 
', b'individuals with external biological sex characteristics  52 
', b'that are irresolvably ambiguous, such as those born with  53 
', b'forty-six XX chromosomes with virilization or forty -six XY  54 
', b'chromosomes with undervirilization;  55 
', b'     b.  Services provided when a physi cian has otherwise  56 
', b'diagnosed an individual with a disorder of sexual  57 
', b'development and determined through genetic or biochemical  58 
', b'testing that the individual does not have normal sex  59 
', b'chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex  60 
', b'steroid ho rmone action; or  61 
', b'     c.  The treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or  62 
', b'disorder that has been caused by or exacerbated by the  63 
', b'performance of gender transition procedures regardless of  64 
', b'whether the gender transition procedure was performed in  65 
', b'accordance with state and federal law;  66 
', b'     (7)  "Genital gender reassignment surgery", a medical  67 
', b'procedure performed for the purpose of assisting an  68 
', b'individual with a gender transition, including, but not  69 
', b'limited to:  70 
', b'     (a)  Surgical procedures such as p enectomy,  71 
', b'orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, or vulvoplasty for  72 
', b'biologically male patients or hysterectomy or ovariectomy  73 
', b'for biologically female patients;  74 
', b'     (b)  Reconstruction of the fixed part of the urethra  75 
', b'with or without a metoidioplast y; or 76 
', b'     (c)  Phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, or  77 
', b'implantation of erection or testicular prostheses for  78 
', b'biologically female patients;  79  SB 164  4 
', b'     (8)  "Health care provider", an individual who is  80 
', b'licensed, certified, or otherwise authorized by the la ws of  81 
', b'this state to administer health care in the ordinary course  82 
', b'of the practice of his or her profession;  83 
', b'     (9)  "Nongenital gender reassignment surgery", medical  84 
', b'procedures performed for the purpose of assisting an  85 
', b'individual with a gender transi tion, including, but not  86 
', b'limited to:  87 
', b'     (a)  Surgical procedures for biologically male  88 
', b'patients, such as augmentation mammoplasty, facial  89 
', b'feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice  90 
', b'surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal augmentation ,  91 
', b'hair reconstruction, or various aesthetic procedures; or  92 
', b'     (b)  Surgical procedures for biologically female  93 
', b'patients, such as subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery,  94 
', b'liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, or various  95 
', b'aesthetic procedures;  96 
', b'     (10)  "Physician", an individual who is licensed under  97 
', b'chapter 334;  98 
', b'     (11)  "Puberty -blocking drugs", gonadotropin -releasing  99 
', b'hormone analogues or other synthetic drugs used in  100 
', b'biological sex males to stop luteinizing hormone secretion  101 
', b'and therefor e testosterone secretion, or synthetic drugs  102 
', b'used in biological sex females that stop the production of  103 
', b'estrogens and progesterone, when used to delay or suppress  104 
', b'pubertal development in children for the purpose of  105 
', b'assisting an individual with a gender  transition.  106 
', b'     3.  A physician or other health care provider shall not  107 
', b'provide gender transition procedures to any individual under  108 
', b'eighteen years of age and shall not refer any individual  109 
', b'under eighteen years of age to any health care provider for  110 
', b'gender transition procedures.  111  SB 164  5 
', b'     4.  Any physician or health care provider who willfully  112 
', b'and knowingly does or assists any prohibited action under  113 
', b'subsection 3 of this section shall have his or her license,  114 
', b'application for license, or authority to pra ctice his or her  115 
', b'profession as a physician, surgeon, nurse, or other health  116 
', b'care provider in the state of Missouri rejected or revoked  117 
', b'by his or her respective licensing board.  118 
', b'     5.  The provision of gender transition procedures to an  119 
', b'individual und er eighteen years of age in violation of the  120 
', b'provisions of this section shall be considered grounds for a  121 
', b'cause of action against the health care provider for  122 
', b'personal injury or death under chapter 538 and such cause of  123 
', b'action shall be governed by the provisions of such chapter.    124 
', b'An individual under eighteen years of age upon whom gender  125 
', b'transition procedures were performed in violation of this  126 
', b'section may bring the cause of action either through a next  127 
', b'friend or his or her own name, subject to the provisions of  128 
', b'section 516.105.  129 
', b'     568.060.   1.  As used in this section, the following  1 
', b'terms shall mean:  2 
', b'     (1)  "Abuse", the infliction of physical, sexual, or  3 
', b'mental injury against a child by any person eighteen years  4 
', b'of age or olde r.  For purposes of this section, abuse shall  5 
', b'not include injury inflicted on a child by accidental means  6 
', b'by a person with care, custody, or control of the child, or  7 
', b'discipline of a child by a person with care, custody, or  8 
', b'control of the child, includi ng spanking, in a reasonable  9 
', b'manner; 10 
', b'     (2)  "Abusive head trauma", a serious physical injury  11 
', b'to the head or brain caused by any means, including but not  12 
', b'limited to shaking, jerking, pushing, pulling, slamming,  13 
', b'hitting, or kicking;  14  SB 164  6 
', b'     (3)  "Mental injury", an injury to the intellectual or  15 
', b'psychological capacity or the emotional condition of a child  16 
', b'as evidenced by an observable and substantial impairment of  17 
', b'the ability of the child to function within his or her  18 
', b'normal range of performance or beh avior; 19 
', b'     (4)  "Neglect", the failure to provide, by those  20 
', b'responsible for the care, custody, and control of a child  21 
', b'under the age of eighteen years, the care reasonable and  22 
', b'necessary to maintain the physical and mental health of the  23 
', b'child, when such  failure presents a substantial probability  24 
', b'that death or physical injury or sexual injury would result;  25 
', b'     (5)  "Physical injury", physical pain, illness, or any  26 
', b'impairment of physical condition, including but not limited  27 
', b'to bruising, lacerations, he matomas, welts, or permanent or  28 
', b'temporary disfigurement and impairment of any bodily  29 
', b'function or organ;  30 
', b'     (6)  "Serious emotional injury", an injury that creates  31 
', b'a substantial risk of temporary or permanent medical or  32 
', b'psychological damage, manifeste d by impairment of a  33 
', b'behavioral, cognitive, or physical condition.   Serious  34 
', b'emotional injury shall be established by testimony of  35 
', b'qualified experts upon the reasonable expectation of  36 
', b'probable harm to a reasonable degree of medical or  37 
', b'psychological cer tainty; 38 
', b'     (7)  "Serious physical injury", a physical injury that  39 
', b'creates a substantial risk of death or that causes serious  40 
', b'disfigurement or protracted loss or impairment of the  41 
', b'function of any part of the body.  42 
', b'     2.  A person commits the offense of abuse or neglect of  43 
', b'a child if such person knowingly causes a child who is less  44 
', b'than eighteen years of age:  45  SB 164  7 
', b'     (1)  To suffer physical or mental injury as a result of  46 
', b'abuse or neglect; or  47 
', b'     (2)  To be placed in a situation in which the child may   48 
', b'suffer physical or mental injury as the result of abuse or  49 
', b'neglect.  50 
', b'     3.  A person commits the offense of abuse or neglect of  51 
', b'a child if such person recklessly causes a child who is less  52 
', b'than eighteen years of age to suffer from abusive head  53 
', b'trauma. 54 
', b'     4.  A person commits the offense of abuse or neglect of  55 
', b'a child if such person coerces a child who is less than  56 
', b'eighteen years of age to undergo any surgical or hormonal  57 
', b'treatment for the purpose of gender reassignment, as such  58 
', b'term is defined in section 191.1720.  59 
', b'     5.  A person does not commit the offense of abuse or  60 
', b'neglect of a child by virtue of the sole fact that the  61 
', b'person delivers  or allows the delivery  of a child to a  62 
', b'provider  of emergency  services.  63 
', b'     [5.]6.  The offense of abus e or neglect of a child is:  64 
', b'     (1)  A class D felony, without eligibility for  65 
', b'probation, parole, or conditional release until the  66 
', b'defendant has served no less than one year of such sentence,  67 
', b'unless the person has previously been found guilty of a  68 
', b'violation of this section or of a violation of the law of  69 
', b'any other jurisdiction that prohibits the same or similar  70 
', b'conduct or the injury inflicted on the child is a serious  71 
', b'emotional injury or a serious physical injury, in which case  72 
', b'abuse or neglect of a child is a class B felony, without  73 
', b'eligibility for probation or parole until the defendant has  74 
', b'served not less than five years of such sentence; or  75  SB 164  8 
', b'     (2)  A class A felony if the child dies as a result of  76 
', b'injuries sustained from conduct chargeable under the  77 
', b'provisions of this section.  78 
', b'     [6.]7.  Notwithstanding subsection [5]6 of this section  79 
', b'to the contrary, the offense of abuse or neglect of a child  80 
', b'is a class A felony, without eligibility for probation,  81 
', b'parole, or conditional release until the defendant has  82 
', b'served not less than fifteen years of such sentence, if:  83 
', b'     (1)  The injury is a serious emotional injury or a  84 
', b'serious physical injury;  85 
', b'     (2)  The child is less than fourteen years of age; and  86 
', b'     (3)  The injury is the result of sexual abuse or sexual  87 
', b'abuse in the first degree as defined under section 566.100  88 
', b'or sexual exploitation of a minor as defined under section  89 
', b'573.023.  90 
', b'     [7.]8.  The circuit or prosecuting attorney may refer a  91 
', b'person who is suspected of abuse or negle ct of a child to an  92 
', b'appropriate public or private agency for treatment or  93 
', b'counseling so long as the agency has consented to taking  94 
', b'such referrals.   Nothing in this subsection shall limit the  95 
', b'discretion of the circuit or prosecuting attorney to  96 
', b'prosecute a person who has been referred for treatment or  97 
', b'counseling pursuant to this subsection.  98 
', b'     [8.]9.  Nothing in this section shall be construed  to  99 
', b'alter the requirement  that every element of any crime  100 
', b'referred  to herein must be proven beyond a reasonable doubt. 101 
', b'     [9.]10.  Discipline, including spanking administered in  102 
', b'a reasonable manner, shall not be construed to be abuse  103 
', b'under this section.  104 
', b'\xef\x83\xbc ']

title: Relating to gender reassignment medical services for minors
description: The purpose of this bill is relating to gender reassignment medical services for minors; making findings and declarations; defining sex; establishing prohibited treatment for minors; providing exceptions; creating responsibilities for school personnel; and establishing consequences for violations of article
history: [{'date': '2023-02-20', 'action': 'Filed for introduction', 'chamber': 'S', 'chamber_id': 2, 'importance': 0}, {'date': '2023-02-20', 'action': 'To Health and Human Resources then Judiciary', 'chamber': 'S', 'chamber_id': 2, 'importance': 0}, {'date': '2023-02-20', 'action': 'Introduced in Senate', 'chamber': 'S', 'chamber_id': 2, 'importance': 1}, {'date': '2023-02-20', 'action': 'To Health and Human Resources', 'chamber': 'S', 'chamber_id': 2, 'importance': 1}]
subjects: [{'subject_id': 29337, 'subject_name': 'Health'}]
text:
[b'
', b'WEST VIRGINIA LEGISLATURE2023 REGULAR SESSIONIntroducedSenate Bill 692By Senators Maynard and Taylor[Introduced February 20, 2023; referredto the Committee on Health and Human Resources; and then to the Committee on the Judiciary]A BILL to amend the Code of West Virginia, as amended, by adding thereto a new article, designated \xc2\xa716-66-1, \xc2\xa716-66-2, \xc2\xa716-66-3, \xc2\xa716-66-4, and \xc2\xa716-66-5, all relating to gender reassignment medical services for minors; making findings and declarations; defining sex; establishing prohibited treatment for minors; providing exceptions; creating responsibilities for school personnel; and establishing consequences for violations of article.Be it enacted by the Legislature of West Virginia:\xc2\xa0
', b'Article 66. Gender reassignment medical services for minors.
', b'
', b'\xc2\xa716-66-1. Findings and Declarations. 
', b'The West Virginia Legislature hereby finds and declares all of the following:(1) This state has a compelling government interest in protecting the health and safety of its citizens, especially vulnerable children;(2) Only a tiny percentage of the American population experiences distress at identifying with their biological sex. According to the American psychiatric association, prevalence ranges from 0.005 to 0.014 percent for natal adult males and from 0.002 to 0.003 percent for natal females;(3) Studies consistently demonstrate that the vast majority of children who are gender non-conforming or experience distress at identifying with their biological sex come to identify with their biological sex in adolescence or adulthood, thereby rendering most medical health care interventions unnecessary;(4) Scientific studies show that individuals struggling with distress at identifying with their biological sex often have already experienced psychopathology, which indicates these individuals should be encouraged to seek mental health care services before undertaking any hormonal or surgical intervention;(5) Suicide rates, psychiatric morbidities, and mortality rates remain markedly elevated above the background population after inpatient gender reassignment procedures have been performed;(6) Some health care providers are prescribing puberty-blocking drugs in order to delay the onset or progression of normally-timed puberty in children who experience distress at identifying with their biological sex. This is being done despite the lack of any long-term longitudinal studies evaluating the risks and benefits of using these drugs for the treatment of such distress or gender transition;(7) Health care providers are also prescribing cross-sex hormones for children who experience distress at identifying with their biological sex, despite the fact that no randomized clinical trials have been conducted on the efficacy or safety of the use of cross-sex hormones in adults or children for the purpose of treating such distress or gender transition;(8) The use of cross-sex hormones comes with the following serious known risks:(A) For biological females, erythrocytosis, severe liver dysfunction, coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, hypertension, increased risk of breast and uterine cancers, and irreversible infertility.(B) For biological males, thromboembolic disease, cholelithiasis, coronary artery disease, macroprolactinoma, cerebrovascular disease, hypertriglyceridemia, breast cancer, and irreversible infertility.(9) Genital and non-genital reassignment surgeries are generally not recommended for children, although evidence indicates referrals for children to have such surgeries are becoming more frequent;(10) Genital gender reassignment surgery includes several irreversible invasive procedures for males and females and involves the following alterations of biologically normal and functional body parts:(A) For biological males, surgery may involve genital reconstruction including penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, and vulvoplasty.(B) For biological females, surgery may involve a hysterectomy or oophorectomy, reconstruction of the urethra, genital reconstruction including metoidioplasty or phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, and implantation of erection or testicular prostheses.(11) The complications, risks, and long-term care concerns associated with genital gender reassignment surgery for both males and females are numerous and complex;(12) Non-genital gender reassignment surgery includes various invasive procedures for males and females and also involves the alteration or removal of biologically normal and functional body parts:(A) For biological males, procedures may include augmentation mammoplasty, facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, and other aesthetic procedures.(B) For biological females, procedures may include subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, and other aesthetic procedures.(13) It is an accepted principle of economics and public policy that when a service or product is subsidized or paid for, demand for that service or product increases. Just between 2015 and 2016, gender reassignment surgeries increased by 20 percent;(14) It is of grave concern to the Legislature that the medical community is allowing individuals who experience distress at identifying with their biological sex to be subjects of irreversible and drastic non-genital gender reassignment surgery and irreversible, permanently sterilizing genital gender reassignment surgery, despite the lack of studies showing that the benefits of such extreme interventions outweigh the risks;(15) The risks of gender transition procedures far outweigh any benefit at this stage of clinical study on these procedures.
', b'\xc2\xa716-66-2. Definition of Sex.
', b'As used in this article, "sex" means the biological indication of male and female, including sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, and nonambiguous internal and external genitalia present at birth, without regard to an individual's psychological, chosen, or subjective experience of gender.
', b'\xc2\xa716-66-3. Prohibited practices.
', b"(a) Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, no physician or other medical health care professional shall knowingly engage in or cause any of the following practices to be performed upon any person under the age of 18 if the practice is performed for the purpose of attempting to alter the appearance of or affirm the minor's perception of his or her gender or sex, if that appearance or perception is inconsistent with the minor's sex as defined in this act:(1) Prescribing or administering puberty blocking medication to stop or delay normal puberty.(2) Prescribing or administering supraphysiologic doses of testosterone or other androgens to females.(3) Prescribing or administering supraphysiologic doses of estrogen to males.(4) Performing surgeries that sterilize, including castration, vasectomy, hysterectomy, oophorectomy, orchiectomy, and penectomy.(5) Performing surgeries that artificially construct tissue with the appearance of genitalia that differs from the individual's sex, including metoidioplasty, phalloplasty, and vaginoplasty.(6) Removing any healthy or non-diseased body part or tissue, except for a male circumcision.(b) No physician, mental health provider, or other medical health care professional shall knowingly engage in conduct that aids or abets the practices described in subsection (a) to any person under 18 years of age. This section may not be construed to impose liability on any speech or conduct protected by federal or state law.(c) Subsections (a) and (b) do not apply to:(1) Services provided to individuals born with a medically verifiable disorder of sex development, including a person with external biological sex characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous, such as an individual born with 46 XX chromosomes with virilization, 46 XY chromosomes with undervirilization, or having both ovarian and testicular tissue;(2) Services provided to an individual when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a disorder of sexual development, in which the physician has determined through genetic or biochemical testing that the individual does not have normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid hormone action for a biological male or biological female;(3) The treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has been caused or exacerbated by the performance of gender transition procedures, whether or not the procedures were performed in accordance with state and federal law;(4) Any procedure undertaken because an individual suffers from a physical disorder, physical injury, or physical illness that is certified by a physician and that would place the individual in imminent danger of death or impairment of major bodily function unless surgery is performed.
", b'\xc2\xa716-66-4. Responsibilities of school personnel.
', b"No nurse, counselor, teacher, principal, or other official or staff at a public or private school shall knowingly do either of the following:(1) Encourage or coerce a minor to withhold from the minor's parent or legal guardian the fact that the minor's perception of his or her gender is inconsistent with his or her sex;(2) Withhold from a minor's parent or legal guardian information related to the minor's perception that his or her gender is inconsistent with his or her sex.
", b'\xc2\xa716-66-5. Violations of article. 
', b"(a) The provision of services described in \xc2\xa716-66-3 of this code to any person under 18 years of age shall be considered unprofessional conduct and shall be subject to discipline by the licensing entity with jurisdiction over the physician, mental health provider, or other medical health care professional.(b) A person may assert an actual or threatened violation of this article as a claim or defense in a judicial or administrative proceeding and obtain compensatory damages, injunctive relief, declaratory relief, or any other appropriate relief.(c) A person shall be required to bring a claim for a violation of this article not later than two years after the day the cause of action accrues. A minor may bring an action before reaching 18 years of age through a parent or guardian, and may bring an action in the minor's own name upon reaching 18 years of age at any time from that point until 20 years after.(d) An action under this article may be commenced, and relief may be granted, in a judicial proceeding without regard to whether the person commencing the action has sought or exhausted available administrative remedies.(e) In any action or proceeding to enforce a provision of this article, a prevailing party who establishes a violation of this chapter shall be entitled to recover reasonable attorneys' fees.(f) The attorney general may bring an action to enforce compliance with this article. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to deny, impair, or otherwise affect any right or authority of the attorney general, the state, or any agency, officer, or employee of the state to institute or intervene in any proceeding.\xc2\xa0NOTE: The purpose of this bill is relating to gender reassignment medical services for minors; making findings and declarations; defining sex; establishing prohibited treatment for minors; providing exceptions; creating responsibilities for school personnel; and establishing consequences for violations of articleStrike-throughs indicate language that would be stricken from a heading or the present law and underscoring indicates new language that would be added."]

text:
[b'FIRST REGULAR SESSION
', b'HOUSE BILL NO. 463 102ND GENERAL ASSEMBLY
', b'INTRODUCED BY REPRESENTATIVE BOYD.
', b'DANA RADEMAN MILLER, Chief Clerk
', b'AN ACT
', b'    2 3
', b'2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9
', b'10
', b'11
', b'12
', b'13
', b'14
', b'15
', b'To repeal sections 568.060 and 578.421, RSMo, and to enact in lieu thereof three new sections relating to gender transition procedures, with penalty provisions.
', b'Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the state of Missouri, as follows:
', b'Section A. Sections 568.060 and 578.421, RSMo, are repealed and three new sections enacted in lieu thereof, to be known as sections 191.1720, 568.060, and 578.421, to read as follows:
', b'191.1720. 1. This section shall be known and may be cited as the "Missouri Save Adolescents from Experimentation (SAFE) Act".
', b'2. For purposes of this section, the following terms mean:
', b'(1) "Biological sex", the biological indication of the physical condition of being male or female, which is determined by an individual's chromosomes, identified at birth by an individual's anatomy, and indicated on the individual's birth certificate, without regard to an individual's psychological, chosen, or subjective experience of gender;
', b'(2) "Cross-sex hormones":
', b'(a) Testosterone or other androgens given to biological sex females in amounts that are larger or more potent than would normally occur naturally in healthy biological sex females; and
', b'(b) Estrogen given to biological sex males in amounts that are larger or more potent than would normally occur naturally in healthy biological sex males;
', b'(3) "Gender", the psychological, behavioral, social, and cultural aspects of being male or female;
', b'EXPLANATION \xe2\x80\x94 Matter enclosed in bold-faced brackets [thus] in the above bill is not enacted and is intended to be omitted from the law. Matter in bold-face type in the above bill is proposed language.
', b'HB 463 2

', b'(4) "Gender reassignment surgery", any medical or surgical service that alters or removes physical or anatomical characteristics of an individual's biological sex for the purpose of gender transition;
', b'(5) "Gender transition", the process in which an individual transitions from his or her biological sex to a gender different from his or her biological sex, which may involve social, legal, or physical changes;
', b'(6) "Gender transition procedures":
', b"(a) Any medical or surgical service, including, but not limited to, physician's services, inpatient and outpatient hospital services, or prescribed drugs, related to gender transition that seeks to:
", b"a. Alter or remove physical or anatomical characteristics or features that are typical for the individual's biological sex; or
", b"b. Instill or create physiological or anatomical characteristics that resemble a sex different from the individual's biological sex including, but not limited to:
", b'(i) Medical services that provide puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, or other mechanisms to promote the development of feminizing or masculinizing features in the opposite biological sex; or
', b'(ii) Genital or nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition;
', b'(b) The term "gender transition procedures" shall not include:
', b'a. Services to individuals born with medically verifiable disorders of sex development, including individuals with external biological sex characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous, such as those born with forty-six XX chromosomes with virilization or forty-six XY chromosomes with undervirilization;
', b'b. Services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed an individual with a disorder of sexual development and determined through genetic or biochemical testing that the individual does not have normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid hormone action; or
', b'c. The treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has been caused by or exacerbated by the performance of gender transition procedures regardless of whether the gender transition procedure was performed in accordance with state and federal law;
', b'(7) "Genital gender reassignment surgery", a medical procedure performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition including, but not limited to:
', b'

', b'(a) Surgical procedures such as penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, or vulvoplasty for biologically male patients or hysterectomy or ovariectomy for biologically female patients;
', b'(b) Reconstruction of the fixed part of the urethra with or without a metoidioplasty; or
', b'(c) Phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, or implantation of erection or testicular prostheses for biologically female patients;
', b'(8) "Health care provider", an individual who is licensed, certified, or otherwise authorized by the laws of this state to administer health care in the ordinary course of the practice of his or her profession;
', b'(9) "Nongenital gender reassignment surgery", medical procedures performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition including, but not limited to:
', b'(a) Surgical procedures for biologically male patients, such as augmentation mammoplasty, facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, or various aesthetic procedures; or
', b'(b) Surgical procedures for biologically female patients, such as subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, or various aesthetic procedures;
', b'(10) "Physician", an individual who is licensed as a physician under chapter 334;
', b'(11) "Puberty-blocking drugs", gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues or other synthetic drugs used in biological sex males to stop luteinizing hormone secretion and therefore testosterone secretion, or synthetic drugs used in biological sex females that stop the production of estrogens and progesterone, when used to delay or suppress pubertal development in children for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition.
', b'3. A physician or other health care provider shall not provide gender transition procedures to any individual under eighteen years of age and shall not refer any individual under eighteen years of age to any health care provider for gender transition procedures.
', b'4. Any physician or health care provider who willfully and knowingly commits or assists any prohibited action under subsection 3 of this section shall have his or her license, application for license, or authority to practice his or her profession as a physician, surgeon, nurse, or other health care provider in the state of Missouri rejected or revoked by his or her respective licensing board.
', b'

', b'88 years of age in violation of the provisions of this section shall be considered grounds for
', b'89 a cause of action against the health care provider for personal injury or death under
', b'90 chapter 538 and such cause of action shall be governed by the provisions of such
', b'91 chapter. An individual under eighteen years of age upon whom gender transition
', b'92 procedures were performed in violation of this section may bring the cause of action
', b'93 either through a next friend or in his or her own name, subject to the provisions of
', b'94 section 516.105.
', b'568.060. 1. As used in this section, the following terms shall mean:
', b'2 (1) "Abuse", the infliction of physical, sexual, or mental injury against a child by any
', b'3 person eighteen years of age or older. For purposes of this section, abuse shall not include
', b'4 injury inflicted on a child by accidental means by a person with care, custody, or control of
', b'5 the child, or discipline of a child by a person with care, custody, or control of the child,
', b'6 including spanking, in a reasonable manner;
', b'7 (2) "Abusive head trauma", a serious physical injury to the head or brain caused by
', b'8 any means, including but not limited to shaking, jerking, pushing, pulling, slamming, hitting,
', b'9 or kicking;
', b'10 (3) "Mental injury", an injury to the intellectual or psychological capacity or the
', b'11 emotional condition of a child as evidenced by an observable and substantial impairment of
', b'12 the ability of the child to function within his or her normal range of performance or behavior;
', b'13 (4) "Neglect", the failure to provide, by those responsible for the care, custody, and
', b'14 control of a child under the age of eighteen years, the care reasonable and necessary to
', b'15 maintain the physical and mental health of the child, when such failure presents a substantial
', b'16 probability that death or physical injury or sexual injury would result;
', b'17 (5) "Physical injury", physical pain, illness, or any impairment of physical condition,
', b'18 including but not limited to bruising, lacerations, hematomas, welts, or permanent or
', b'19 temporary disfigurement and impairment of any bodily function or organ;
', b'20 (6) "Serious emotional injury", an injury that creates a substantial risk of temporary or
', b'21 permanent medical or psychological damage, manifested by impairment of a behavioral,
', b'22 cognitive, or physical condition. Serious emotional injury shall be established by testimony
', b'23 of qualified experts upon the reasonable expectation of probable harm to a reasonable degree
', b'24 of medical or psychological certainty;
', b'25 (7) "Serious physical injury", a physical injury that creates a substantial risk of death
', b'26 or that causes serious disfigurement or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any
', b'27 part of the body.
', b'28 2. A person commits the offense of abuse or neglect of a child if such person
', b'29 knowingly causes a child who is less than eighteen years of age:
', b'5. The provision of gender transition procedures to an individual under eighteen
', b'
', b'5
', b'(1) To suffer physical or mental injury as a result of abuse or neglect; or
', b'(2) To be placed in a situation in which the child may suffer physical or mental injury as the result of abuse or neglect.
', b'3. A person commits the offense of abuse or neglect of a child if such person recklessly causes a child who is less than eighteen years of age to suffer from abusive head trauma.
', b'4. A person commits the offense of abuse or neglect of a child if such person coerces a child who is under eighteen years of age to undergo any surgical or hormonal treatment for the purpose of gender transition, as defined in section 191.1720.
', b'5. A person does not commit the offense of abuse or neglect of a child by virtue of the sole fact that the person delivers or allows the delivery of a child to a provider of emergency services.
', b'[5.] 6. The offense of abuse or neglect of a child is:
', b'(1) A class D felony, without eligibility for probation, parole, or conditional release until the defendant has served no less than one year of such sentence, unless the person has previously been found guilty of a violation of this section or of a violation of the law of any other jurisdiction that prohibits the same or similar conduct or the injury inflicted on the child is a serious emotional injury or a serious physical injury, in which case abuse or neglect of a child is a class B felony, without eligibility for probation or parole until the defendant has served not less than five years of such sentence; or
', b'(2) A class A felony if the child dies as a result of injuries sustained from conduct chargeable under the provisions of this section.
', b'[6.] 7. Notwithstanding subsection [5] 6 of this section to the contrary, the offense of abuse or neglect of a child is a class A felony, without eligibility for probation, parole, or conditional release until the defendant has served not less than fifteen years of such sentence, if:
', b'(1) The injury is a serious emotional injury or a serious physical injury;
', b'(2) The child is less than fourteen years of age; and
', b'(3) The injury is the result of sexual abuse or sexual abuse in the first degree as
', b'defined under section 566.100 or sexual exploitation of a minor as defined under section 573.023.
', b'[7.] 8. The circuit or prosecuting attorney may refer a person who is suspected of abuse or neglect of a child to an appropriate public or private agency for treatment or counseling so long as the agency has consented to taking such referrals. Nothing in this subsection shall limit the discretion of the circuit or prosecuting attorney to prosecute a person who has been referred for treatment or counseling pursuant to this subsection.

', b'578.421. 1. Sections 578.421 to 578.437 shall be known and may be cited as the
', b'2 "Missouri Criminal Street Gangs Prevention Act".
', b'3 2. As used in sections 578.421 to 578.437, the following terms mean:
', b'4 (1) "Criminal street gang", any ongoing organization, association, or group of three or
', b'5 more persons, whether formal or informal, having as one of its motivating activities the
', b'6 commission of one or more of the criminal acts enumerated in subdivision (2) of this
', b'7 subsection, whose members individually or collectively engage in or have engaged in a
', b'8 pattern of criminal gang activity;
', b'9 (2) "Pattern of criminal street gang activity", the commission, attempted commission,
', b'10 or solicitation of two or more of the following offenses, provided at least one of those
', b'11 offenses occurred after August 28, 1993, and the last of those offenses occurred within three
', b'12 years after a prior offense, and the offenses are committed on separate occasions, or by two or
', b'13 more persons:
', b'14 (a) Assault with a deadly weapon or by means of force likely to cause serious
', b'15 physical injury, as provided in sections 565.050 and 565.052;
